Physical examination reveals a heart murmur consistent with aortic stenosis. He denies any familial history of premature heart disease. His medications are Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol consumer. He is slightly overweight (BMI: 26 kg/m2) and a retired teacher who lives with his wife. He denies any drug allergies.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer with a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents in the outpatient clinic complaining of worsening shortness of breath on exertion  occasional chest tightness  and decreased exercise tolerance over the past 6 months. He denies smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use  but admits to a sedentary lifestyle. Family history is notable for a brother who had coronary artery disease. On physical examination  auscultation reveals a late-peaking  harsh systolic ejection murmur best heard over second right intercostal space that radiates to the neck. No peripheral edema is noted on examination. The patient's symptoms and examination findings are suspicious for aortic valve stenosis.

A 75-year-old white male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and uncontrolled type 2 diabetes presents with exertional dyspnea and angina for 6 months. The patient reports a decrease in exercise tolerance  grades it at NYHA class III. The patient also mentions episodes of presyncope with the onset of extreme fatigue but denies any history of syncope. He denies any associated cough  fever  or palpitations. The patient has a 40 pack year smoking history and drinks alcohol socially. He has a family history of heart disease  with his father having a myocardial infarction in his sixties. Physical exam reveals a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space that radiates to the neck  consistent with aortic valve stenosis. The patient is visibly uncomfortable and displays distress during the examination. The rest of the examination  including lung auscultation  is within normal limits.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  a former smoker  is presented in the clinic. He complains of chronic exertional dyspnea  worsening over the last three months  accompanied by occasional chest discomfort and episodes of lightheadedness. He also reported two episodes of syncope in the last month  more recently while climbing stairs. He has limited his daily activities to avoid these symptoms. His family history is notable  with his father having had heart surgery but the details are unclear. The outlook specifically points towards possible aortic valve stenosis.

An 73-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history pertinent for untreated hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with gradually progressive exertional dyspnea over the last 6 months. He also reports increased fatigue  episodic chest pain during exertion  and a fainting episode last week. On physical examination  a prominent systolic heart murmur with a slow-rising carotid pulse is noticed. His EKG shows evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient denies any familial history of cardiovascular diseases or sudden cardiac death. He is an ex-smoker and quit smoking 15 years ago. He admits minimal adherence to a properly balanced diet and does not engage in routine physical exercises. With the current lifestyle and clinical presentation  suspicion is high for aortic valve stenosis. His reported symptoms align with notable cardinal symptoms including dyspnea  chest pain (angina)  and syncope  especially under exertion. His age  unchecked hypertension  and untreated hyperlipidemia are significant risk factors.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of long-standing untreated hypertension comes into the office complaining of dyspnea on exertion  chest tightness  and episodes of lightheadedness for the past two months. He admits his symptoms have been progressively worsening  now occuring even at rest. He reveals a family history of heart disease  with his father having died due to a heart attack at the age of 70. He admits to smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily since he was 30 years old. Upon auscultation  a harsh systolic murmur  best heard at the upper right sternal border  is evident. Pulses are diminished in comparison to prior visits. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Taken together  these findings suggest a presentation of aortic valve stenosis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a documented history of high blood pressure and coronary artery disease presents with symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath especially on exertion  and fatigue. After an initial evaluation  he is identified as having a faint systolic murmur upon auscultation. He highlights an increased number of episodes of angina during the past month and mentions that his daily routine is becoming more strenuous due to increased fatigue and dyspnea. His family points out that he also experienced episodes of syncope in the past weeks. Investigations including an echocardiogram confirm the diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient with a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia presents with exertional dyspnea and episodes of syncope in the past few months. He also reports angina-like chest pain during regular activities. He has been previously treated for ischemic heart disease. On further physical examination  a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur audible at the second right intercostal space along with delayed carotid upstroke is noted. The patient's description of his symptoms  his medical background and the physical findings brings forth a strong suspicion of aortic valve stenosis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with symptoms of exertional dyspnea  chest pain  and episodes of syncope for the past six months. On review  the patient also reports unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite. He was a smoker for 40 years but quit 10 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally. The patient has a positive family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died at the age of 65 due to a myocardial infarction. Physical examination reveals a diminished  delayed carotid pulse (termed ""pulsus parvus et tardus"") and an ejection systolic murmur best heard over the right second intercostal space  radiating to the neck (carotids). These symptoms and signs suggest aortic stenosis  which is a common heart condition in the elderly  especially those with a damaging lifestyle and genetic predisposition. This condition requires further evaluation and management  using imaging studies like an echocardiogram to assess severity and determine the appropriate therapeutic approach.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for untreated hypertension and mild dyslipidemia  now presents to the cardiology clinic with complaints of increasing exertional dyspnea and decreased exercise tolerance over the past six months. He also reports episodes of dizziness and occasional fainting. His symptoms have progressively worsened and now he is unable to perform regular activities such as climbing stairs or walking. On examination  a systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border is noticed  which radiates to the neck and increases in intensity with inspiration. An EKG showed left ventricular hypertrophy. Based on his age  symptoms  and initial clinical findings  the patient's presentation is highly suggestive of Aortic Valve Stenosis. His untreated hypertension could be a potential contributing factor to the development of this condition.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with complaints of dyspnea on exertion  angina  and intermittent episodes of dizziness over the past 6 months. He has been increasingly fatigued and finding it difficult to complete regular activities such as gardening or walking up a flight of stairs without needing to rest.  He reports never smoking but has a light-moderate alcohol consumption history. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease with his father having had a myocardial infarction in his 70s. He was not on any anticoagulant therapy but was managing his conditions with lifestyle interventions and Lipitor for his hyperlipidemia. He had no known drug allergies.  On examination  he had a prominent systolic ejection murmur best heard in the right second intercostal space with radiation to the neck. His blood pressure reading was slightly elevated. The patient also displayed sluggish carotid upstrokes. EKG showed some minor non-specific ST wave changes  but notably  he had significant left ventricular hypertrophy on the echocardiogram with a significantly reduced aortic valve area indicating severe aortic stenosis.  The described symptoms paired with the significant findings in his cardiovascular examination suggest the patient's aortic valve stenosis has been worsening  causing his left ventricle to work increasingly harder to pump blood through the narrowed valve and causing him these symptoms. Because of increasing symptom severity and echocardiographic evidence of the severity of the stenosis  valve replacement may be appropriate.

A 72-year-old African-American male presents with progressive dyspnea and exertional angina over the past 8 months. He has a known medical history of hypertension and mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  both of which have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. Additionally  he was diagnosed with aortic stenosis two years ago via echocardiogram during a routine check-up. He has not had any surgical interventions for his aortic stenosis. He was a smoker for 50 years and quit five years ago but has a moderate alcohol intake. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has a family history of heart disease. He currently lives alone and is retired.   On physical examination  he has an audible late-peaking systolic murmur in the aortic area of the heart which proxies for the severity of the stenosis. The pulse in his radial and carotid arteries appear sluggish (pulsus parvus et tardus). His blood pressure is elevated at 150/90 mmHg. Lung auscultation reveals faint crackles at the lung bases  suggestive of mild pulmonary congestion often associated with severe aortic stenosis due to increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure. There are no signs of heart failure such as pedal edema or jugular venous distention. Electrocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy  consistent with long-standing increased afterload need due to aortic stenosis. His condition has likely progressed and might be approaching severe aortic stenosis. The dyspnea and exertional angina can be explained by the reduced cardiac output due to the aortic stenosis  which is exacerbated by physical exertion.

An 74-year-old Caucasian male with a longstanding history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia is presenting with progressive exertional dyspnea  fatigue  and occasional chest discomfort over the past 6 months. He was previously quite active  but now he is unable to take his daily walks without feeling winded. In addition  patient mentions experiencing few episodes of dizziness in the last month. Patient denies fever  cough  hemoptysis  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or palpitations. He is a non-smoker with moderate alcohol use. He has remained adherent to his antihypertensive and statin medications. Family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. On examination  his vital signs are stable but there is an ejection crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard in the right second intercostal space  radiating to the carotids. This clinical presentation raises suspicion for aortic valve stenosis.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a thirty-year pack history of smoking  presents with worsening exertional dyspnea  angina  and episodic presyncope over the past six months. Physical examination reveals a late peaking systolic murmur heard best in the right second intercostal space suggestive of aortic valve stenosis. These symptoms  accompanied by the patient's advanced age and extensive medical history  highlight a high likelihood of severe  symptomatic aortic valve stenosis due to calcific disease  which is the predominant cause in developed countries among adults over the age of 75. Additional diagnostic evaluations  including an echocardiogram  will be necessary to confirm diagnosis and guide therapeutic decisions.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic complaining of exertional dyspnea  fatigue  and occasional chest discomfort for the last 6 months. He also notes episodic episodes of lightheadedness. He has no known food allergies. He quit smoking 10 years ago but has a 40 pack-year history. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies use of illicit drugs. He has not had previous major surgeries. Family history reveals that his father passed away from a myocardial infarction in his 60s.   On examination  the patient has a slow-rising pulse and narrow pulse pressure. A cardiovascular examination reveals a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border with radiation to the carotids. These findings are suggestive of aortic valve stenosis.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male presents with exertional dyspnea  orthopnea  and intermittent episodes of dizziness for the past few months. These symptoms have been progressively worsening. He has a former history of untreated hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. His body mass index is 27. Physical examination reveals a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space  which radiates to the neck. The patient also has palpable thrills  and echocardiogram findings are consistent with severe aortic valve stenosis. A dense  calcified aortic valve with reduced opening and an aortic jet velocity of ~5 m/s confirm the severity of stenosis.

An 77-year-old Caucasian male presents with progressive shortness of breath on exertion and recurrent episodes of syncope. He has a known history of heart murmur identified in adolescence  but he has not sought or received regular cardiac follow-up. Over the past few months  his symptoms  including fatigue  decreased exercise tolerance and chest heaviness  have not only worsened but also started to impact his day-to-day life. Additionally  the patient reports a history of smoking over 50-pack years and occasional alcohol intake  no known drug allergies  and a family history of heart diseases. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  leg swelling  nocturnal dyspnea  or orthopnea. His blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  pulse 72 beats/min  BMI 27. On clinical examination  the clinician notes a grade 3/6 late peaking systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border  radiating to the neck and no peripheral edema. A suspicion of severe aortic valve stenosis is raised and further diagnostic tests like ECG  Echocardiography and  if needed  Cardiac Catheterization are planned to confirm diagnosis and evaluate disease severity.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents to the clinic with progressively worsening shortness of breath  especially during exertion  over the past six months. He has also noted a weight gain of 10 pounds along with swelling in ankles. He denies any chest pain  but occasionally experiences dizziness and near syncope while getting up from a seated position. He has bruits heard over the carotids bilaterally and upon auscultation of heart  there is a harsh systolic murmur heard best at right second intercostal space. He is a nonsmoker and denies any family history of heart diseases. On further evaluation  he is found to have aortic valve stenosis.

A 73-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with progressive exertional dyspnea  chest pain  and episodes of syncope over the past six months. He has a 50-pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur  best heard at the right second intercostal space  radiating to the carotids. The patient also shows signs of decreased exercise tolerance and has frequent fatigue episodes. He denied past incidences of rheumatic fever. His long-term medications include Atorvastatin 20mg daily and Lisinopril 10mg daily. His symptoms of exertional dyspnea  angina  and syncope  along with the murmur auscultated on physical examination  suggest moderate-to-severe aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with past medical history notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and episodic chest discomfort for several months. On examination  he was found to have a diminished second heart sound  along with a systolic ejection murmur best heard over the right upper sternal border with radiations to the carotids. The patient reports experiencing increased fatigue  mild lightheadedness  and occasional syncope over the past two weeks. His EKG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and a chest x-ray revealed cardiac enlargement. The patient has no known allergies  does not smoke  drinks alcohol occasionally  and has a family history of heart diseases. His current medications include Hydrochlorothiazide and Atorvastatin. These findings suggest severe aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with shortness of breath  especially on exertion  decreased exercise tolerance  and occasional chest pain. The chest pain is described as a dull ache  without any correlation to exertion or rest. His family history is significant for heart disease  with both his father and grandfather having passed away from myocardial infarctions in their early 60s. He is a former smoker  with a history of smoking about 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 50 years. He quit smoking 10 years ago but continues to consume alcohol moderately. He reports a significant weight gain over the past few months. On examination  a systolic heart murmur  loudest at the right second intercostal space  is noted  which radiates to the carotids. His pulses are slow-rising and there is a notable delay between the apex beat and the carotid pulse. Given these symptoms and physical findings  aortic valve stenosis is suspected. He was referred for an echocardiogram for further evaluation.

A 74-year-old white male presents to the clinic with a recent history of increasing exertional breathlessness and some episodes of dizziness over the past few months. He reports feeling his heart ""pounding"" in his chest  often associated with mild chest discomfort. In the recent weeks  he noted these symptoms begin to occur even while at rest. Evaluation reveals a noticeable heart murmur.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension  controlled with medication  and longstanding smoking habit which he quit 10 years ago. He has taken a baby Aspirin daily for the past several years on the recommendation of his primary care physician.  On examination  he appears fatigued but is not in acute distress. His blood pressure is slightly elevated  with a narrow pulse pressure. Cardiovascular examination reveals a harsh  crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best in the right second intercostal space  and radiates to the carotid arteries. Initial investigations including echocardiography point towards a diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian woman presents with dyspnea upon exertion  chronic fatigue  and episodes of fainting. The patient has a known history of hypertension and high cholesterol  both of which have been managed through medication for the past 10 years. She reports a gradual worsening of her symptoms over the past six months. During physical examination  she exhibits a systolic heart murmur. Her echocardiogram confirms moderate to severe aortic valve stenosis without evidence of heart failure. The patient has no known allergies  is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. She has a family history of heart diseases with her late mother having had a coronary artery bypass surgery at the age of 75.

An 80-year-old  Hispanic female presents with complaints of recent onset exertional dyspnea  intermittent chest pain  and episodes of fainting. The patient is an active member of her local community. She has a medical history of hypertension for 20 years which is currently controlled with medication. Her father died at an early age due to cardiac problems  but she does not know the specifics. Physical examination reveals a systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation  suggestive of aortic stenosis. She has a BMI of 28 and does not engage in tobacco use or excessive alcohol consumption. She acknowledges her diet could be healthier  consisting primarily of traditional Hispanic dishes high in carbohydrates and fats. On further questioning  she admits to experiencing an intermediate decline in daily activities due to her symptoms.

Patient Profile: Caucasian male  70 years old.  Presenting Issue: He is experiencing recurrent episodes of dizziness and chest discomfort that are worsening in frequency and severity over the past three months. He also experiences worsening fatigue after mild exertion  such as a short walk or climbing stairs. There have been no instances of fainting.  Relevant Medical History: He has been diagnosed with hypertension for a decade  and has a ten-year history of moderate to severe dyslipidemia  both are being managed with medication. There is a positive family history of cardiac diseases  with his father experiencing a myocardial infarction in his sixties.  Pertinent Examination Findings: On examination  the patient is slightly tachypneic. The cardiac auscultation reveals a systolic murmur at the second right intercostal space that radiates to the carotid arteries.   Interpretation: Given the age  presentation  and examination findings  the patient's symptoms may be due to aortic valve stenosis. This is supported by the patient's dyspnea  fatigue after mild exertion  chest discomfort  and the harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space. However  further diagnostic workup through echocardiography is required for a definitive diagnosis.

An 80-year-old Caucasian male presents with an increasing shortness of breath over the last 6 months  specifically on exertion while walking up the stairs or gardening. His medical history reveals long-standing non-insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus; there are no known allergies. Over the last two months  he has occasionally experienced chest pain during exertion  which eases during rest. Patient also mentions some episodes of dizziness. He reports no orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or ankle swelling. No history of smoking or alcohol intake. Patient's father died of a heart attack.  Patient appears comfortable at rest but becomes short of breath with minimal exertion. His vital signs are as follows: BP 138/85  Pulse: 92  Resp: 18  SpO2: 95% RA. Cardio exam reveals a harsh systolic murmur best heard at the upper right sternal border. The rest of the physical exam  including pulmonary  abdominal  and neurological  is within normal limits.  These findings raise the suspicion of chronic aortic valve stenosis perhaps secondary to age-related calcific changes or modulated by his diabetic state.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with progressive exertional dyspnea  fatigue  and occasional chest pain over the past six months. The patient has a history of long-standing hypertension  and reports that recently these symptoms have begun to limit his daily activities. He denies symptoms of syncope  palpitations  peripheral edema  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He has been a non-smoker for the last 20 years and consumes alcohol occasionally. On examination  an ejection systolic murmur can be heard best at the right upper sternal border  along with a delayed and diminished carotid pulse. ECG reveals left ventricular hypertrophy. This clinical picture is suggestive of aortic valve stenosis  notably common among the elderly and male population. Further investigations  including an echocardiogram  are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and determine severity.

A 74-year-old Caucasian male  an ex-smoker with a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with gradually worsening exertional dyspnea over the last six months. He also mentions occasional episodes of dizziness and fainting  especially during strenuous activity  with one recent fall reportedly leading to a hip injury. Additionally  he complains of occasional chest discomfort  described more like a heaviness rather than pain. He has never had diagnostic imaging or interventions related to cardiac issues. He is currently on antihypertensive medications and statins. On examination  he appears mildly dyspneic  with visible early fatigue. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space  radiating to the carotids with a slow-rising  diminished carotid upstroke. Lung auscultation and other systems are unremarkable. Based on his presentation  significantly decreased exercise tolerance  and physical examination signs  he appears to have symptomatic severe aortic stenosis.

A 75-year-old Caucasian female presents to the outpatient clinic with recent onset of exertional dyspnea  fatigue and frequent episodes of dizziness over the past three months. She has a history of rheumatic fever in her youth  hypertension for the past 10 years managed with antihypertensive medications  and hyperlipidemia managed with statins. She is a former smoker and quit smoking 10 years ago after a 30-year history of one pack per day. The patient also occasionally experiences chest pain and palpitations. She is retired  lives with her husband  and has no history of alcohol or substance abuse. Her father died of a heart attack at the age of 70. On physical examination  a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard in the right second intercostal space is noted  along with a slow carotid pulse. She has no lower extremity edema. Labs show normal electrolytes  kidney function  liver function and complete blood count. Echocardiography reveals left ventricular hypertrophy along with calcification and narrowing of the aortic valve with reduced valve area  consistent with aortic stenosis.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with dyspnea  chest discomfort  and syncope  each progressively worsening over the last several months. The patient has a relevant medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well-managed with medication. Further  the patient reports a family history of heart disease  with his father having required a coronary artery bypass graft in his sixties. On physical exam  a medium-pitched harsh systolic ejection murmur maximally heard at the right second intercostal space along the sternal border radiating to the carotid arteries suggests an etiology of aortic valve stenosis. The patient denies smoking and risky alcohol consumption but admits to a sedentary lifestyle.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of congestive heart failure and chronic hypertension presents with progressive exertional dyspnea  episodes of dizziness  and occasional chest discomfort that has worsened over the last three months. He also mentions experiencing reduced capacity for physical activity and fatigue. He denies any recent illnesses  changes in medications  or travel history. No prior surgeries or known allergies. He is a lifelong non-smoker with occasional alcohol use. Family history is significant for heart disease. On examination  a harsh ejection systolic murmur was noted. No edema or cyanosis is evident. His heart rate is regular but bradycardic. Investigations including ECG and echocardiography have been initiated.

A 70-year-old Caucasian man presents with progressive shortness of breath  chest pain  and frequent episodes of dizziness over the past six months. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and a 10-year history of smoking  quit 15 years ago. On examination  the patient has an apical impulse felt at the fifth intercostal space mid-clavicular line  a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border  and late-peaking upstrokes in his carotid arteries. He has decreased exercise tolerance and recent weight gain due to fluid retention. This presentation is suggestive of severe aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with progressive shortness of breath on exertion  slight chest discomfort  and occasional episodes of dizziness over the last six months. Patient also reports recent syncope during mild exertion with rapid recovery. He has a known history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  and is a long-term smoker. He has had no previous surgeries or hospitalizations. Family history is significant for heart disease. On physical examination  a systolic heart murmur is noted. His blood pressure is slightly elevated  and ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. The symptoms  physical findings  and past medical history are suggestive of aortic valve stenosis.

An 80-year-old Caucasian male  retired military officer  presents with symptoms of ongoing fatigue  chest pain  and shortness of breath. The patient has a known history of hypertension and coronary artery disease  for which he has been taking low-dose aspirin and Atorvastatin 10mg daily for two years. The patient is also a former smoker with 30 pack-years.   The onset of symptoms started about 6 months ago  with notable worsening in the last two months. The patient reports a progressive decline in his ability to perform daily tasks due to fatigue and the necessity to frequently rest because of the feeling of breathlessness. In addition  his chest pain  described as crushing and heavy  is mostly exertional  and it often radiates to his left arm  also being relieved with rest.  On physical examination  he has a noticeable systolic ejection murmur that is heard best at the upper right sternal border and the carotid arteries.    The combination of the patient’s age  symptoms  and the auscultation findings suggests the possible diagnosis of severe symptomatic aortic stenosis. Diagnostic workup with echocardiography is recommended.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with increasing fatigue  shortness of breath  and chest pain for the past several months. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a smoking history of 30 pack years but quit 10 years ago. He has been previously treated with statins and antihypertensives. The fatigue is activity-related  and the chest pain is relieved with rest. He has occasional palpitations  lightheadedness and a single episode of syncopal attack. On evaluation  a harsh systolic murmur is noted that radiates to the carotids. An echocardiogram performed shows calcified aortic valve with reduced opening. The calculated aortic valve area is less than 1 cm2 congruent with diagnosis of severe aortic stenosis.

A 68-year-old African-American man presents with fatigue and shortness of breath  particularly during exertion. He has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he takes medication. The patient reports he has been feeling an intermittent chest pain over last few months  which he initially attributed to age and overwork. He mentioned that over the past few weeks  he was forced to stop his routine morning walks because he felt like he was running out of breath. He also noted a faint yet uncomfortable feeling of his heart pounding or beating rapidly  especially during the night. His family history includes a father with coronary artery disease and a brother who had aortic valve repair. He has been a non-smoker  consumes alcohol occasionally  and follows a moderate exercise routine. On examination  a mid-systolic murmur was obvious on the second right intercostal space radiating to the neck  suggesting aortic valve stenosis.

A 71-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with progressive exertional dyspnea over the past six months. He further reports episodes of angina-like chest pain and light-headedness  particularly with exertion. The patient also notes reduced exercise tolerance  which now limits his daily activities. Family history reveals his father had a cardiac surgery but patient does not recall the specifics. Despite the discomfort  he denies any episode of syncope. The patient is a retired administrative office worker and denies any tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. On examination  he is found to have a delayed and diminished carotid upstroke and an auscultatory examination reveals a late peaking systolic murmur. Due to these symptoms  patient is suspected to have aortic valve stenosis.

Patient Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of smoking and hypercholesterolemia  presents with progressive fatigue  exertional dyspnea  and recent intermittent episodes of angina over the past six months. The patient also reports a few episodes of fainting within the last month. His mother suffered from heart disease but the details are indistinct. He reports minimal alcohol intake and quit smoking 10 years ago. He denies fever  chills  and other systemic symptoms.   On examination  harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best at right second intercostal space with radiation to the carotids  delayed carotid upstroke  and reduced intensity of the second heart sound are noted. His blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg  and he has a regular pulse rate of 72 beats per minute. There are no signs of heart failure. An electrocardiogram reveals left ventricular hypertrophy with strain pattern.  The symptoms and signs in combination with the patient’s age  history of smoking  and hypercholesterolemia lead to high suspicion for aortic valve stenosis possibly progressing to severe  based on the symptoms of angina  syncope  and heart failure. Further diagnostic tests  including an echocardiogram  are required to confirm the diagnosis. The patient needs immediate attention as this condition can be life-threatening without intervention.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with a six-month history of progressive shortness of breath on exertion and recent episodes of syncope. He has a past medical history of hypertension  which has been controlled with medication for the last 20 years  a high LDL cholesterol level and prior positive smoking status (40 pack-years). He leads a largely sedentary lifestyle and has familial history of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. On physical examination  there is an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space and radiating toward the carotid arteries  accompanied by delayed and weak carotid pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus). There's no palpable thrill in the suprasternal notch or over the carotids suggesting severe stenosis. Echocardiogram confirms severe calcific aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of long-standing  untreated hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic with gradually worsening shortness of breath  chest pain  and episodes of dizziness over the past six months. He reports experiencing exertional dyspnea noticeable while walking up one flight of stairs  and occasional anginal chest tightness  which resolves at rest. He also describes two episodes of presyncope within the last month  with no loss of consciousness. He denies palpitations  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.  On physical exam  he has a slow-rising pulse  decreased first heart sound (S1)  and a harsh ejection systolic murmur best heard over the right upper sternal border  radiating to the neck. Lung fields are clear on auscultation. Blood pressure is maintained (120/85 mmHg). The patient has no pitting edema on his lower limbs.  The patient's clinical presentation and physical findings are suggestive of aortic valve stenosis with symptoms typically manifesting after the sixth decade of life and more prevalent in males. His untreated hypertension and hyperlipidemia are known risk factors for aortic stenosis. The dizziness and presyncope episodes suggest a compromised cardiac output.

An 80-year-old Caucasian female presents with increasing fatigue and shortness of breath  especially while climbing stairs or walking long distances. She has noticed uncomfortable chest tightness over the last few months and has had two episodes of fainting spells with exertion. She denies any palpitations  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Relevant past medical history includes controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago but did not require any surgical intervention. Family history is positive for cardiovascular diseases  particularly her father who had aortic valve stenosis. She has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit 20 years ago. Current medications include aspirin  atorvastatin  and metoprolol. On examination  her blood pressure is within normal limits  but there is a noticeable slow-rising pulse. Cardiac examination reveals a soft S2 with a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border that radiates to the carotids. No peripheral edema or jugular venous distention are observed. An initial diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis is suspected considering her age  symptoms and examination findings.

A 75-year-old white male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and previous smoking presents with worsening shortness of breath  chest pain  and episodes of lightheadedness on exertion over the past six months. His symptoms have produced significant functional limitation  restricting the patient to activities requiring low-level exertion. He reports a decreased exercise tolerance and has noted an increasing difficulty in climbing stairs. The patient also endorses a recent episode of syncope two weeks prior. A heart murmur was detected on his last physical examination  two years prior. His blood pressure on presentation is 145/90 mmHg. He has been adherent to lifestyle modifications and his current medications include a beta-blocker  statin  and aspirin. Family history includes father and brother who suffered from heart conditions in their late 70s.

Subject: A 72-year-old African American male.  Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  the patient has a 10-year history of well-controlled type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. He also has a history of occasional smoking in the past but quit five years ago. There is no known family history of any heart disease.  Presentation: The patient presents with progressive exertional dyspnea  angina during periods of activity  and a recent episode of syncope which occurred during a brisk walk. He reports that he has been feeling the above symptoms gradually worsening over the past few months. On physical examination  there is a noticeable decrease in the volume and delayed peaking of carotid pulse  often described as 'parvus et tardus.' There is an ejection systolic murmur that is heard best at the upper right sternal border and radiates to the carotid arteries.  Probable Diagnosis: These symptoms and signs are suggestive of severe aortic valve stenosis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history notable for hypertension and mild hyperlipidemia  non-smoker  presents with a 3-month history of exertional dyspnea and recent onset of angina. Patient also reports noticeable periods of lightheadedness and one syncopal episode in the past month  all during physical exertion. The family history is significant for his father who had a stroke at the age of 75. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic ejection murmur best heard in the right upper sternal border  irradiating to the neck. There is also an elevated pulse pressure and reduced intensity of the S2 heart sound. His electrocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient's symptoms  physical examination findings  and electrocardiogram are suggesting aortic valve stenosis.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male with history of untreated hypertension for 10 years and a 40 pack-year smoking history presents with exertional dyspnea and chest pain for the past 6 months. Previously he could walk around the park without any discomfort but now he struggles to walk a few blocks without becoming breathless. He also mentions occasional episodes of dizziness.  Physical examination reveals a diminished second heart sound and a mid systolic ejection murmur heard best at the base of the heart  radiating to the carotids. His blood pressure reading is high at 170/90 mm Hg. Electrocardiogram (ECG) displays left ventricular hypertrophy.   This clinical picture is suggestive of aortic valve stenosis  likely a consequence of his longtime untreated hypertension and heavy smoking history. He will likely need further assessment including an echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis and assess severity.

An 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and former heavy smoking habits has presented with progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue over the past several months. Recently  he started to experience episodes of anginal chest pain and fainting spells. He is adherent to his medications which include aspirin  beta-blocker  and a statin. He has quit smoking more than a year ago. His mother had a history of heart disease. On examination  his blood pressure is 140/80 mmHg and heart rate is 68 bpm. An early peaking  harsh systolic murmur can be heard on auscultation at the right upper sternal border  classically associated with aortic stenosis. The patient's distal pulses appear weak and delayed  providing further clinical suspicion of aortic stenosis. Electrocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Primary medical problem: suspected severe symptomatic aortic valve stenosis.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with symptoms of worsening exertional dyspnea  occasional 'heart fluttering'  and lightheadedness over the past 6 months. He used to golf every day but now finds it hard to complete a round without getting breathless. He also reports angina-like chest pain with exertion that resolves with rest. He has no history of smoking  diabetes  or drug use. He has a 30-year history of hypertension well controlled with lisinopril and a 20-year history of hyperlipidemia managed with simvastatin. He does not report any family history of premature coronary artery disease or sudden cardiac death. On examination  he has an ejection systolic murmur heard best at the base of the heart. Based on these clinical findings  the patient is likely dealing with aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents complaining of worsening exertional dyspnea and intermittent chest discomfort over the past six months. The patient has a known history of aortic valve stenosis diagnosed two years ago  and has been medically managed thus far due to a preference to avoid surgery. He also suffers from hypertension  currently controlled with medications. The patient is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago. On physical examination  the patient exhibits an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space and radiating to the carotids indicative of significant aortic stenosis. He also displays shortness of breath after climbing a flight of stairs indicative of reduced exercise tolerance. The patient's symptoms in combination with his known history of stenosis indicate a probable worsening of his condition  which transfers him into a high risk category of rapid disease progression  hence warranting reconsideration of surgical options.

A 82-year-old Caucasian female presents with signs of fatigue  shortness of breath on exertion  and intermittent chest pain which frequently occur during exercise. She reports a history of heart murmur  identified several years ago but not followed up. The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managing it through diet and oral medication respectively. Personal history suggests that she was a smoker for 30 years  having quit 20 years ago. The patient's family history is notable for ischemic heart disease  her father having received a coronary artery bypass graft in his sixties. She denies any current medication use other than her chronic conditions. On physical examination  an early peaking  slow-rising pulse was noted  accompanied by a noticeable systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. These features are indicative of aortic valve stenosis  necessitating further cardiac evaluation.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic with exertional dyspnea and chest discomfort that he has noticed over the past few months. He reports a gradual progression of these symptoms  now occurring with minimal activities such as walking around his home. He also mentions occasional episodes of syncope when standing up. He was previously active and had a good exercise capacity but has noticed a drastic decrease recently. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes every day for the last 30 years and has an occasional alcohol intake. He denies any history of rheumatic fever in his childhood. There is a history of cardiovascular disease in his family; his father had a myocardial infarction at 70.  On examination  he exhibits a reduced pulse pressure and the presence of a late peaking systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border  which radiates to the neck. These symptoms and signs are suggestive of aortic stenosis  possibly caused by degenerative valve disease compounded by his risk factors which include advanced age  male gender  smoking history  and the presence of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

Patient Profile: A 71-year old Caucasian male retired professional with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Chief Complaint: The patient reports recent episodes of exertional chest pain and increased dyspnea over the past few months.  History of Present Illness: Exertional chest pain (angina)  worsening dyspnea  and fatigue have been gradually increasing for the last 4 months. The patient also mentions occasional lightheadedness. He denies both orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Has concluded outdoor jogging due to dyspnea and fatigue. There is no reported history of syncope.  Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension for 10 years and hyperlipidemia for 5 years by his primary care provider  both controlled moderately with medication. The patient has a familial history of heart disease  with his father having had a heart attack in his early 70s.  Review of Systems: Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  a regular pulse of 78 beats per minute. There is a systolic ejection murmur heard at the right second intercostal space which radiates to the carotid arteries. The rest of the examination is normal.  Conclusion: These symptoms and physical exam findings are common with elderly patients having aortic valve stenosis. The history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia further increases the risk of cardiovascular disease in this patient. The patient’s age  symptoms  and physical exam findings suggest severe aortic stenosis  which requires urgent evaluation and management  most likely aortic valve replacement.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with complaints of progressively worsening fatigue  shortness of breath  particularly after physical activity  and occasional lightheadedness over the last six months. Recently  he has also started experiencing occasional chest pain or tightness. He has a past medical history of hypertension and known for bicuspid aortic valve  but no known history of coronary artery disease or diabetes. He was a smoker for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. Family history is significant for aortic valve disease in his father. On examination  there is a prominent systolic murmur audible at the upper right sternal border. EKG reveals left ventricular hypertrophy  and an echocardiogram later confirms the suspected diagnosis of severe aortic valve stenosis.

An 80-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with complaints of chest pain  dyspnea  and syncope. He has a known history of moderate-severe aortic valve stenosis diagnosed three years ago  managed conservatively with regular cardiology follow-ups. The patient has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  with no significant history of smoking  alcoholism  or drug abuse. Family history includes cardiovascular diseases  predominantly in male relatives. He describes increasing instances of exertional dyspnea over the last 6 months  with more recent episodes of angina and two episodes of syncope within the past two weeks. He has worsened functional capacity  unable to walk more than a few blocks without needing to stop because of breathlessness and fatigue. Symptom worsening correlates with his latest echocardiography  which showed progression of the aortic valve stenosis.

A 78-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and a 40-year history of heavy smoking presents with worsening dyspnea on exertion and occasional episodes of chest pain over the past six months. He reports a progressive decline in activity tolerance  experiencing breathlessness even while performing his daily household chores. He also reports intermittent episodes of light-headedness. He denies any palpitations  syncope  or orthopnea. On examination  there are classic findings of a harsh systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border that radiates to the neck  diminished and delayed carotid pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus)  and a soft second heart sound (A2). There is no peripheral edema or jugular venous distension suggestive of congestive heart failure. These clinical features are highly suggestive of severe aortic valve stenosis  likely of degenerative etiology given his age and smoking history.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male with a relevant medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with symptoms of exertional dyspnea  chest tightness  dizziness  and occasional fainting episodes. He is a non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption. He was diagnosed with a heart murmur on routine examination 5 years ago. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border  radiating to the neck  suggesting likely aortic valve stenosis. His symptoms have been increasing in frequency and severity over the past two months. The patient's father had similar symptoms and died at the age of 70 due to heart complications.

A 70-year-old African American man with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with recent onset chest discomfort  exertional dyspnea  and decreased exercise tolerance over the past 6 weeks. Physical examination reveals a late-peaking systolic murmur with a palpable thrill on the right second intercostal space. Additionally  the patient's pulse appears diminished and slow to rise ('pulsus parvus et tardus'). Hence  these findings suggest aortic valve stenosis.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  with a 10-year history of poorly controlled hypertension and 40 pack-year smoking history  presents with a two-month history of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and chest tightness. He also reports episodes of exertional syncope and increasing fatigue over the past month. He denies any recent illnesses or changes in his medications. He has an established diagnosis of hyperlipidemia managed with statins and type 2 diabetes maintained by metformin. He has no known allergies.   Physical examination reveals an early-peaking systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space that radiates along the left sternal border. The murmur is associated with a delayed and diminished carotid upstroke. He has a normal S2 and no diastolic murmur  heart rate is 80 beats per minute  blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg  respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. There is no evidence of volume overload during the examination. There is no calf tenderness or swelling suggestive of deep vein thrombosis. Lab tests include a complete blood count  basic metabolic panel  and a lipid panel which reveals hyperlipidemia. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows left ventricular hypertrophy and a chest X-ray reveals a slightly enlarged cardiac silhouette without pulmonary congestion.  This clinical vignette represents the typical presentation of aortic valve stenosis. This condition is typically seen in older adults and the patient's history of long-term hypertension and smoking provides structural strain on the valve  leading to progressive narrowing and stenosis. Symptoms such as dyspnea  angina  and syncope are classical triad for aortic valve stenosis that occur later in the course of the disease due to diminishing cardiac output caused by the stenosis. An early-peaking systolic murmur associated with delayed carotid upstroke is suggestive of aortic stenosis. Further diagnostic evaluation with echocardiography is needed to confirm the diagnosis. Antibiotic prophylaxis prior to dental procedures may be necessary in this patient due to the risk of endocarditis.

An 80-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and angina over the period of a year. He reports occasional syncope  associated with exertional activities. On examination  the patient demonstrates systolic ejection murmur heard best at right upper sternal border which intensifies with Valsalva maneuver. The pulse pressure is narrowed. He denies any history of smoking or alcohol consumption. His father had a history of aortic stenosis. He currently takes a Thiazide diuretic  a beta blocker  and a statin. He lives independently and previously could walk three blocks without needing to rest. He has now noticed he gets breathless on walking entrally between two side streets.

Demographic Details: A 70-year-old  Caucasian male  Relevant Medical History: A former smoker with a 30-year pack history. Has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with medication. There is no reported family history of heart disease.  Presenting Complaints/symptoms: The patient presents with progressive exertional dyspnea over the past six months  occasional chest pain  and episodes of lightheadedness. The chest pain occurs mostly at rest but also during moderate activities like walking uphill. He mentions a fainting episode a month ago. He also reports reduced stamina  as he can no longer keep up with the physical activities he used to enjoy  like golfing. In addition  he has been experiencing intermittent nocturnal dyspnea.  On examination  the patient is afebrile with stable vital signs  but his pulse is noted to have a reduced volume. There is a delayed and diminished radial pulse together with a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the right second intercostal space  radiating to the carotids. These findings are attributed to aortic stenosis  possibly severe  given the presence of symptoms and delayed  reduced volume pulse.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension presents to the clinic with symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and chest pain. Symptoms have been noticed over the last three months and have progressively worsened over this period. The patient also describes two episodes of syncope that occurred in the past month. He has a significant past medical history of hypertension  which has been well-controlled with medication over the last 10 years. The patient denies any family history of cardiomyopathy or sudden cardiac death. On physical examination  a reduced intensity of the second heart sound  along with a systolic ejection murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space  is noted  indicative of potential aortic stenosis. There are no signs of leg swelling or congestion in the lungs on examination  arguing against heart failure at this point.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents for a routine medical examination. He reports a decrease in exercise tolerance over the past six months  with increasing breathlessness during minimal exertion such as during climbing a flight of stairs. He also reports occasional episodes of chest discomfort and episodes of dizziness. He denies any syncope  palpitations  or swelling in his legs. On examination  the patient exhibits a slow-rising  weak pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus)  and an early peaked  harsh systolic murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space that radiates into the neck (carotids). These findings are suggestive of aortic valve stenosis.

An 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic reporting symptoms of progressive exertional dyspnea  fatigue  occasional lightheadedness  and chest tightness  especially during physical exertion over the past three months. Fiscal stress is also present as the patient reports late responses to medical bills. These symptoms in combination with his medical history are suggestive of aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with a six-month history of decreasing exercise tolerance  increasing shortness of breath during exertion  and a few incidences of feeling faint  which he attributes to 'age and lack of fitness'. He denies having any chest pain. He has a past medical history of hypertension  which is being managed with Lisinopril 10mg daily  and a 40-pack-year smoking history  though he quit smoking about 12 years ago. The patient's father had a heart condition but details are unclear. On physical examination  a prominent 3rd heart sound (S3) and systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space  radiating to the carotids was noted. EKG shows left ventricular hypertrophy which raises suspicion of aortic stenosis due to the patient's symptoms and physical findings.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male presents with complaints of increasing fatigue  especially noted with physical exertion  and occasional chest tightness for the past few months. He also reports shortness of breath  notably while climbing stairs and a single episode of feeling light-headed and nearly fainting about two weeks ago. He has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia that is managed with medication. Denies any history of smoking  alcohol  or recreational drug use. The patient has been generally active and independent in the past with no record of cardiovascular diseases or surgeries. His father had the late-onset of coronary artery disease. Physical examination reveals a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best in the right second intercostal space.   This information would fit a typical case of aortic stenosis in a high-risk  elderly patient. The patient's symptoms of fatigue  breathlessness on exertion  chest discomfort  and dizziness  along with the physical finding of a systolic murmur  make the presence of aortic valve stenosis highly likely. The patient's age  race  and male sex are congruent with a higher prevalence of aortic stenosis in elderly  Caucasian males. The known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia adds to the patient’s risk profile for aortic valve disease.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of chronic hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with progressively worsening exertional dyspnea over the past six months. He also reports recent onset of chest discomfort during physical activity and some episodes of near-syncope. He denies any history of rheumatic fever. On examination  an ejection systolic murmur is noted. These symptoms and physical findings are suggestive of aortic valve stenosis.

A 70-year-old  Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50 pack-year smoking history  presents to the clinic with increasing fatigue  exertional dyspnea  and episodes of syncope over the last six months. Following referral from his primary care physician due to an unexpected heart murmur  an echocardiogram confirms the suspicion of aortic valve stenosis. Additionally  the patient reports a recent decline in exercise tolerance  needing to rest after walking short distances. There is no reported chest pain or discomfort. He has never had a similar episode in the past  and he denies associated symptoms of palpitations  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or lower extremity edema. His maternal grandfather underwent aortic valve replacement surgery at an advanced age for valve disease. The patient's current medications include amlodipine  and atorvastatin. The patient is retired  does not consume alcohol and quit smoking 10 years ago.

A 77-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  chronic kidney disease and mild left ventricular hypertrophy presents with an increasing shortness of breath  reduced endurance during exercise  and occasional chest tightness over the past 6 months. The patient also reported a 'heart murmur' noted on his last comprehensive check-up a year ago  but no follow-up was done. Physical examination shows an ejection systolic murmur loudest in the second right intercostal space  radiating to the neck. The symptoms suggest progressive aortic valve stenosis. His blood pressure is moderately controlled while his cholesterol levels are high despite medication therapy. Any chest pain  palpitations  sudden weight loss  night sweats  changes in bladder or bowel habits  or any other systemic complaints are absent. The patient is of normal weight for his height. He has quit smoking 20 years ago and drinks alcohol casually. He lives alone since his wife's passing 8 years ago  is independent in his daily activities  and denies any history of substance abuse. He was a schoolteacher by profession. Family history includes an elder brother who died due to a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. The patient does not have any known allergies. The working diagnosis is symptomatic moderate to severe aortic valve stenosis.

Patient is an 82 year-old Caucasian male with a relevant medical history of longstanding untreated hypertension  presenting symptoms of increasing exertional dyspnea  chest pain  and episodes of dizziness over the last 6 months. On physical examination  he exhibits a decreased intensity of the second heart sound  a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the upper right sternal border  and displaced apex beat. His BP is 130/80 mmHg and pulse is slow rising. These symptoms associated with clinical-findings suggest the likelihood of aortic valve stenosis. The patient's age  gender and comorbidity of hypertension are all risk factors for the development of this condition.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents with episodes of exertional dyspnea  angina  and occasional lightheadedness over the last six months. His relevant past medical history includes hypertension managed with ACE inhibitors and a history of smoking for over 40 years  quit 10 years ago. He has been increasingly finding it difficult to engage in his routine activities like walking long distances or climbing stairs due to his complaints. On further questioning  he also admits to experience episodes of syncopal attacks. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father having succumbed to a myocardial infarction. Physical examination reveals a systolic ejection murmur best heard in the right second intercostal space and radiating to the neck. His EKG indicates left ventricular hypertrophy. The initial suspicion is of aortic valve stenosis further warranting an echocardiogram.

An 70-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with exertional dyspnea and episodes of dizziness over the past 6 months. He also reports a decreased exercise tolerance and occasional chest discomfort. He quit smoking 10 years ago and has a family history of heart disease. On physical examination  he displays a slow-rising  low-volume pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus). Auscultation of the heart reveals a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border  radiating to the carotid arteries. The patient is currently on anti-hypertensive medication and statins. The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with progressive shortness of breath  chest pain  and feeling of faintness during exertion. He reports symptoms have been progressively worsening over the last six months. He denies any cough  fever  or recent illnesses. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history and reports occasional alcohol use. Physical examination reveals a systolic heart murmur  best heard at the second right intercostal space and radiating to the carotids  diminished pulses  and displaced point of maximal impulse. An echocardiogram was suggestive of calcified aortic valve with restricted opening. The clinical findings and investigations point towards aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with a history of intermittent mild dyspnea on exertion and angina  that has progressively increased over the past few months. The patient also reports occasional syncope. His medical history reveals long-standing hypertension  and he is known to be a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago. His father died at 68 from congestive heart failure of unknown etiology. His physical exam reveals a noticeable heart murmur  characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at the right 2nd intercostal space  radiating to the neck. His vitals are BP 150/80 mmHg  pulse 80 regular  respiratory rate 16 unlabored. Additional workup includes a transthoracic echocardiogram  which supports the suspected diagnosis of aortic stenosis. The patient has a reduced aortic valve area and impaired left ventricular function  indicative of advanced aortic stenosis.

Problem Representation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 30 pack-years of smoking presents to the cardiology clinic with progressive exertional dyspnea and angina over the past six months. The patient also reports a recent development of orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  and occasional episodes of syncope on exertion. On physical examination  the patient appears fatigued with a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. The rest of the cardiovascular examination is unremarkable. The patient denies any previous surgical history  and reports that his father had ""heart disease"". His current medications include atorvastatin and lisinopril. He has an allergy to sulfa-based drugs. His mental status is intact and his vitals include a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and a heart rate of 88 bpm. Laboratory tests reveal normal complete blood count and chemistry panels  but elevated LDL cholesterol. EKG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and a chest X-ray shows cardiac enlargement. His echocardiogram shows a mean pressure gradient of 50 mmHg across the aortic valve with a valve area of 0.6 cm2  indicating severe aortic valve stenosis.

Problem: A 72-year-old white male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with exertional dyspnea (difficulty in breathing while exercising) and fatigue for the last 6 months. He reports recent development of chest discomfort on exertion  relieved by rest. He has a known murmur as described in his medical history which was recently diagnosed as aortic stenosis on an echocardiogram. His physical examination reveals a harsh systolic murmur best heard in the left upper sternal border. The patient denies any history of rheumatic fever. EKG shows left ventricular hypertrophy but no ST-segment or T-wave changes. He is a former smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. His medication regimen includes a beta-blocker for his hypertension and a statin for his hyperlipidemia. No known allergies noted. His BMI is within the normal range. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases with his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. He has not had any surgical interventions nor has he had bacterial endocarditis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male retired engineer presents with increasing exertional dyspnea over the past six months. He has a history of systemic hypertension controlled with therapy and hyperlipidemia. His mother had a history of heart disease. The patient reports intermittent chest tightness during climbing stairs or any other strenuous activity but denies any symptoms at rest. He also reports experiencing episodes of light-headedness and a fainting spell last week. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs but admits drinking alcohol socially. He denies any recent changes in weight  appetite or bowel habits. On examination  his blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg  heart rate of 80 bpm  and BMI within normal range. Respiratory and neurological examinations are unremarkable  and cardiovascular examination reveals a late-peaking systolic murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space. Echocardiogram displays aortic valve leaflet thickening and reduction in the aortic valve area indicating aortic valve stenosis. He does not have any signs suggestive of endocarditis. The resting EKG is normal without signs of left ventricular hypertrophy or a previous myocardial infarction.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents with increasing fatigue and shortness of breath over the last three months  especially during moderate exertion. The patient also reports experiencing occasional chest pain and fainting spells. He has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication  with no record of rheumatic fever or connective tissue disorders. He is still socially active but has significantly reduced his physical activities due to his symptoms. On examination  his vitals are stable  and cardiovascular examination reveals a systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. No jugular venous distension or peripheral edema is noted. This patient’s symptomatology along with physical findings suggest a diagnosis of aortic stenosis  possibly due to age-related calcification given his risk factors and age demographic. A prompt echocardiographic evaluation is warranted to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of aortic stenosis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and longstanding tobacco use  presents with progressively worsening shortness of breath and exertional fatigue over the past 6 months. He also mentions a recent onset of occasional lightheadedness and chest discomfort  particularly when attempting to do household chores. Family history is positive for heart disease including his father who underwent aortic valve replacement at a similar age. On physical examination  a systolic ejection murmur is noted along the right upper sternal border. Rest of the physical examination is essentially within normal limits. Initial suspicion is narrowing of the aortic valve or aortic valve stenosis  likely due to underlying calcific degenerative changes.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male farmer presenting with increasing fatigue and a several-week history of dyspnea on exertion  and episodes of chest tightness. He also occasionally notes lightheadedness  especially after physical activities. He has a history of mild hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide and recently diagnosed hyperlipidemia. He was a 35-pack-year smoker  but quit 10 years ago.   His paternal grandfather died of a ""heart problem"" in his 70s. There's a positive family history of heart disease  with his older brother undergoing open-heart surgery at his early 70s for unknown cardiac reason.   Physical exam reveals a prominent systolic ejection murmur heard best along the right upper sternal border  radiating to the neck. The patient appeared slightly uncomfortable during the examination process. He demonstrates no lower extremity edema and his lung auscultation indicates clear breath sounds bilaterally.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with a recent history of exertional dyspnea  chest pain  and episodes of syncope. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension controlled with medication and was a smoker for 20 years but quit 15 years ago. Rrecently  the patient has also noted decreased exercise tolerance and fatigue. His father died of a heart condition  but the patient is unsure of the specifics. On physical examination  a harsh systolic murmur is heard at the right second intercostal space radiating to the carotid arteries. Based on these symptoms  the suspected diagnosis is aortic valve stenosis. Further diagnostic evaluation including echocardiogram and cardiac catheterization is warranted to confirm the diagnosis and to determine severity of the stenosis  which will guide management and possible necessity of aortic valve replacement.

An 70-year-old Caucasian male presents with shortness of breath on exertion  intermittent chest pain  feeling of fatigue and episodes of fainting. As per the history  the symptoms have been progressing over the past six months. He has a past medical history of hypertension and mild coronary artery disease  and no history of rheumatic heart disease or congenital heart diseases. His father had died of heart failure and he has a brother who underwent aortic valve surgery. On examination  the patient appears in moderate distress  with a harsh systolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex. There may be a delayed and weakened pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus). He is a former smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. His BMI is 28 and he is otherwise quite physically active. EKG shows left ventricular hypertrophy  an echo is pending. These findings are consistent with aortic valve stenosis.

Patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian male  former smoker with a past medical history significant for hypertension and coronary artery disease. He presents with progressive symptoms of exertional dyspnea  angina  and episodes of syncope over the past six months. On physical examination  patient has a slow-rising carotid pulse and a late-peaking  crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. Comparative evaluation of the patient's symptoms in combination with his demographics and medical history indicate the presence of aortic valve stenosis.

An 82-year-old Caucasian male presents with a six-month history of worsening exertional dyspnea and two episodes of near-syncope on exertion. The patient also reports increasing fatigue and has reduced his daily activities significantly due to these limitations. He has a history of stage 2 hypertension under control with thiazide and ACE inhibitors and a 40-pack-year smoking history  but quit 10 years ago. He also has hyperlipidemia which is managed with statin therapy. His father had a cardiac episode in his early 60s. On physical examination  he is noted to have a slow-rising  diminished carotid pulse and a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur loudest at the upper sternal border with radiation to the neck. Echocardiography reveals calcific aortic valve stenosis with a severely reduced valve area.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking presents to the clinic with exertional dyspnea and chest tightness for the past three months. Recently  he has started experiencing lightheadedness on standing up. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the upper right sternal border. He is noted to have a slow-rising  delayed carotid pulse. His EKG shows possible left ventricular hypertrophy. These findings are consistent with suspected moderate-severe aortic valve stenosis.

Patient profile: A 75-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History: He suffers from hypertension and had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago that was managed by coronary artery stenting. Additionally  he has a 20-year history of hypercholesterolemia and is a former smoker  quitting 5 years ago. He follows a routine of cardiac rehabilitation and medication  which includes aspirin  a statin  and an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. He has no known allergies.  Presenting complaint: The patient reports experiencing progressive exertional dyspnea over the past 6 months and now feels fatigued even while resting. Over the last two weeks  he's also developed chest pain on moderate exertion and has to stop frequently during his daily walks.   Symptoms: His presenting symptoms include moderate angina  syncope  and shortness of breath  especially on exertion. On physical examination  he shows a slow-rising  low-amplitude pulse and a mid-systolic ejection murmur at the upper right sternal border with radiation to the carotids. No other prominent physical findings. No symptoms of heart failure or stroke.  All these symptoms are suggestive of a complication secondary to aortic valve stenosis with a likely critical aortic valve area. Further confirmation through trans-thoracic echocardiography (TTE) and coronary angiography is recommended  along with consultation of a Cardiovascular team to discuss the possibility of invasive procedures like aortic valve replacement (surgical or transcatheter) based on the prognosis and patient's wishes.

An 80-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presents with shortness of breath  chest pain  and reduced exercise tolerance over the past three months. The patient also reports episodes of syncope in the last few weeks. On examination  a harsh systolic ejection murmur is noted on the right upper sternal border with radiation to the carotids. The patient's symptoms combined with the physical findings suggest progressing aortic valve stenosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with a recent history of fatigue  dyspnea on exertion  and intermittent chest pain. On further inquiry  he also admits to feeling lightheaded during his daily walks. All these symptoms have been progressing over the past six months. He has a past medical history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension  both of which are controlled on medication.
