Management: The patient was stabilized with diuretic therapy and then undergo trans-catheter aortic valve replacement given the high operative risk due to her age and past medical history. Her post-procedure period was uneventful  and she was discharged home in stable condition  with an outpatient follow-up with a cardiologist scheduled in a month.  7. Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of considering a diagnosis of aortic stenosis in elderly patients with breathlessness  chest discomfort  or fainting. Early recognition and intervention are crucial to prevent progression to heart failure or sudden cardiac death that this disease may cause. The management of aortic stenosis should focus on relieving symptoms and improving life span through aortic valve replacement when indicated.

Title: A Case Report of Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Caucasian Male Patient  Case Presentation: The patient is a 78-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the cardiology clinic with complaints of exertional dyspnea and angina that had been progressing for past three months.  Past Medical History: He has a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he has been taking a calcium channel blocker along with metformin. The patient is an ex-smoker with a 30 pack-year history and quit smoking ten years ago. There's no significant history of rheumatic heart disease  endocarditis  or family history of congenital heart disease.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient had an apical impulse in the fifth intercostal space mid-clavicular line and a harsh systolic ejection murmur that is loudest at the upper right sternal border  radiating to the carotids. The remainder of examination was within normal limits and the patient does not have clinical features of heart failure.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Echocardiography revealed concentric left ventricular hypertrophy and a calcified aortic valve with reduced opening. Doppler echocardiography showed a peak velocity of 5 m/sec across the valve  with a mean pressure gradient of 60 mmHg  and a calculated aortic valve area of 0.7 cm2. These findings are consistent with severe aortic stenosis. An electrocardiogram showed signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. His coronary angiography was positive for moderate (50%) stenosis in the left anterior descending artery.   Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: Given the severity of the patient’s symptoms and the precariously narrowed aortic valve opening  it was decided that the patient would benefit from aortic valve replacement. The patient was counseled about the different types of replacement valves and the possible need for future anticoagulation therapy in case of a mechanical valve replacement.   Follow-Up and Outcome: The patient opted for a biological valve replacement and underwent uncomplicated aortic valve replacement surgery. Post-operative period was uneventful. On follow-up after 3 months  the patient reported significant improvement in his dyspnea and angina was completely resolved. Follow-up echocardiography showed a well-functioning replacement valve with normal left ventricular function.   This case underscores the importance of a thorough cardiovascular examination in the elderly with cardiac symptoms and highlights the potential of aortic valve replacement to dramatically improve symptoms and quality of life in those diagnosed with severe aortic stenosis.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed satisfaction with his progress  reporting a remarkably improved quality of life. He credited his improvement to the medical and surgical team's effective treatment strategy.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for their anonymized information to be published in this article.

Title: A Case Report of an Elderly Female Patient with Aortic Valve Stenosis   Patient Demographics:  The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian female  residing in a suburban area in the northern part of the United States. She lives on her own  though she has a home health aide assisting her regularly due to her age and medical conditions. She is a retired teacher and is widowed  with two adult children and four grandchildren. The patient is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol.   Presenting Complaints:   The patient presented with several episodes of fainting  unsteady gait  and intermittent chest discomfort over the course of two weeks. She has also been experiencing progressive fatigue and shortness of breath over the past few months.  Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension  which was diagnosed around 15 years ago and is managed by a diuretic (25 mg Hydrochlorothiazide daily). She also has a history of hyperlipidemia  and she has been prescribed atorvastatin (20 mg daily). The patient has been compliant with her medications. No known allergies. She underwent surgery for left hip replacement five years ago but does not currently have any orthopedic concerns.   Physical Examination:  Upon examination  she appeared frail and fatigued. Her vital signs were within normal ranges  but her blood pressure was slightly elevated (148/92 mmHg). Cardiovascular examination revealed a harsh  midsystolic ejection murmur heard best at the right sternal border  indicating possible aortic stenosis.  Investigations:  An ECG demonstrated left ventricular hypertrophy  and a subsequent transthoracic echocardiography confirmed the diagnosis of aortic valve stenosis. The echocardiogram showed severe aortic stenosis with a calculated aortic valve area of 0.8 cm². There was evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy and moderate left atrial enlargement. There was also some mild mitral regurgitation.   Outcome and Management:  In light of her symptoms and severe aortic stenosis  as per American Heart Association guidelines  the patient was a candidate for aortic valve replacement. Given her age and frail state  she was evaluated and considered a better candidate for transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) as compared to surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR). The surgery was successful with no immediate complications.  Follow up:   At her three-month post-procedure follow-up appointment  she reported a significant reduction in symptoms including less shortness of breath and fewer episodes of chest discomfort. She continues to be followed regularly by her primary care physician and cardiologist. Current prescriptions include a beta-blocker (Carvedilol 12.5 mg twice daily) and her previous hypertensive and hyperlipidemia medications. She has been encouraged to maintain low salt and low cholesterol diet to assist with the management of her hypertension and hyperlipidemia  respectively.   Informed Consent:   The patient's consent to report this case was obtained. No identifiable information has been disclosed in this report.  Authors:   (Names  Affiliations  Contact Information)  Date:   (To be filled based ondate report is completed)

Title: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in an 82-Year Old Caucasian Female with History of Hypertension: A Case Report   Patient Information:  Mrs. A  an 82-year-old Caucasian female  was referred to our cardiology department with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath  especially while performing household chores. The patient had been experiencing an increasing severity of these symptoms over the last six months. She is a retired school teacher  has never smoked  and drinks alcohol occasionally. Her past medical history revealed that she was diagnosed with hypertension when she was 66 years old  for which she has been on regular medication.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient showed signs of limited cardiac output including fatigue  low-pitched  rough heart murmur  which is characteristic sign of aortic stenosis  and inability to perform high level activities without provoking symptoms. The patient's body mass index (BMI) was 26 kg/m2  blood pressure was 155/90 mmHg  and heart rate was 82 beats per minute.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An electrocardiogram (EKG) demonstrated left ventricular hypertrophy  a common sign of aortic stenosis likely resulting from persistent high pressure in the left ventricle as it works harder to pump blood through the narrowed aortic valve. Transthoracic echocardiography  performed next  affirmed the diagnosis of severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 0.8 cm2 (normal is 2-4 cm2) and the left ventricle showed further signs of thickening due to the hypertension.  In view of her age  computed tomography angiogram was also performed to evaluate the coronary arteries and revealed no significant obstructions. Routine blood tests were within normal limits  and no signs of anemia or renal dysfunction were observed.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was advised aortic valve replacement surgery  considering the severity of the stenosis and the symptomatic nature of her case. However  due to her advanced age and potential surgical risks  she opted for a less invasive Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) procedure  which was carried out successfully without any complications.  Follow-up and Outcome:  Post-TAVR  the patient's symptoms dramatically improved  with a significant easing of her previous breathlessness and chest pain. Repeat echocardiography showed a well-functioning prosthetic valve with a valve area of 1.7 cm2. Post-operative rehabilitation and management of her hypertension were provided.  Conclusion:  In elderly patients with severe aortic stenosis and high surgical risk  TAVR provides a safe and effective alternative. Managing concomitant conditions  in this case  hypertension  is crucial in optimizing the clinical outcomes.  Clinical Pearls:  1. Aortic stenosis may present late and gradual  often mistaken for aging-related decrements in function. 2. The presence of symptoms in a patient with severe aortic stenosis warrants urgent evaluation for aortic valve replacement. 3. Management of co-existing conditions such as hypertension plays a key role in optimizing the patient's clinical outcomes after aortic valve replacement.    Patient Consent: Consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this clinical case report.

Title: Severe Symptomatic Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Male  Patient Description:   Mr. A is a 77-year-old Caucasian male  retired  with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus. His cardiogenic family history is significant  with his father having suffered a fatal myocardial infarction at 72 years old. Mr. A has been a non-smoker for 20 years  having quit a 30-pack-year habit. He maintains a fairly healthy diet and participates in mild  routine physical exercise.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the clinic with complaints of progressive dyspnea and exercise intolerance for the past few months. He also reported several instances of exertional angina and two episodes of syncope in the past six weeks.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  the patient was conscious  alert  but appeared fatigued. Vitals checked out with blood pressure measure at 135/85 mmHg and a heart rate of 78 beats/min. Cardiac auscultation revealed a grade 4/6 ejection systolic murmur consistent with aortic stenosis. There were no signs of peripheral edema  ascites  or cyanosis.   Diagnostic Assessment and Intervention:  Lab results including complete blood count  liver function tests  and renal function tests were within normal ranges  except for slightly elevated HbA1c (7.3%) and LDL cholesterol (160 mg/dL). An electrocardiogram indicated left ventricular hypertrophy. Patient was referred for an echocardiogram  which demonstrated severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 0.8 cm²  peak jet velocity of 4.3 m/s  and a mean gradient of 47mmHg. The left ventricular ejection fraction was 50%  suggesting preserved overall systolic function.  With the clinical presentation and diagnostic findings  the patient was diagnosed with severe symptomatic aortic valve stenosis.   Management and Follow Up:  Given the patient’s advanced age and co-morbidities  he wasn't deemed suitable for surgical valve replacement. Instead  he was referred to a multidisciplinary heart team to evaluate the appropriateness of performing a Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR). The patient was also started on beta-blockers to control symptoms of angina and syncope. His anti-hypertensive treatment plan was adjusted  and lifestyle and dietary modifications were advised to better control his diabetes and hyperlipidemia. Regular follow-ups were scheduled to monitor his clinical status and symptoms.   Discussion:  This case highlights the typical presentation of severe aortic stenosis in elderly individuals  often associated with co-morbidities like hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes. The management of such cases necessitates a comprehensive  individualized approach  considering patient age  overall health status  and the potential risks and benefits of various treatment options.

Title: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in an 80-year-old Female Patient with Preexistent Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  Introduction: Aortic valve stenosis (AS) is the most common valvular heart disease in the elderly and is often associated with other age-related comorbidities. This case report describes the diagnosis  treatment approach  and patient outcome of an octogenarian with AS  who had a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Case Presentation:  Demographic Information: The patient was an 80-year-old Caucasian woman  living a non-active lifestyle in a suburban region of New York  USA. She is a retired teacher and widow with 2 children and 4 grandchildren. She has a history of smoking but quit 25 years ago.  Presenting Conditions: She presented to the clinic with progressive dyspnea on exertion  occasional chest tightness  and fatigue over the past 6 months.   Past Medical History: Her medical history was significant for systemic hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medications (Losartan 50mg daily  Rosuvastatin 10mg daily). She also had occurrences of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) with no residual deficits and was on Clopidogrel (75mg daily) as secondary prevention. Her mother had a history of heart disease. She was not diabetic and there was no history suggestive of Rheumatic heart disease.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  a systolic murmur was heard at the upper right sternal border with radiations to the carotids. The electrocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy. Blood pressure was 145/85 mmHg with a pulse of 78 bpm.  Investigations: Transthoracic echocardiography exhibited a severely calcified aortic valve  reduced leaflet mobility  with peak and mean transvalvular gradients of 74 mmHg and 44 mmHg  respectively  consistent with severe AS. Left ventricular hypertrophy was also noted.   Treatment and Outcome: Considering her symptoms and echocardiographic findings  the patient was referred to undergo transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR)  given her age and other comorbidities. Post-TAVR  her symptoms significantly improved with no procedural complications. She was discharged with life-long Aspirin and a dual antiplatelet regimen of Clopidogrel for six months.  Conclusion: This case underlines the importance of considering AS in elderly patients presenting with dyspnea and fatigue  particularly those with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The choice of TAVR proved to be critical in the successful management of her AS symptoms while also taking into account her age and chronic conditions.   Despite the relatively high prevalence of AS in the aging population  the optimal treatment approaches remain complex because of the patient's comorbidities. This case emphasizes the need for a tailored approach to the management of AS  especially in the elderly population. Early diagnosis and intervention can lead to significantly improved prognosis and quality of life.

Title: Aortic Stenosis in a 64-Year-Old African-American Male: A Case Report  Introduction  Aortic Stenosis (AS) is a heart condition that restricts the blood flow from the left ventricle to the aorta. This condition is typically caused by age-related changes and may lead to heart failure if left untreated. However  symptoms often do not appear until the condition has significantly advanced. Here  we present a novel case of a patient with asymptomatic severe aortic stenosis discovered due to routine medical check-up.  Case Description  The patient is a 64-year-old African-American male with a BMI of 27.3 suggesting overweight. He is a non-smoker and does not have a history of illicit drug use. The patient has a history of controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes for the past ten years  which is well-managed with medication.  The patient came for a routine physical examination  with no complaints of any cardiac symptoms like chest pain  dyspnea  syncope  or heart palpitations. In addition  the patient denied having any changes in exercise tolerance.  On physical examination  the patient had an early peaking  mid-systolic murmur heard best at the second right intercostal space. Some peripheral signs of aortic stenosis such as diminished and delayed carotid upstroke (pulsus parvus et tardus) were also found. The remainder of his examination was unremarkable.   Given the suspicion of AS from clinical evaluation  a echocardiogram was scheduled. This revealed a severely calcified aortic valve with restricted opening  confirming the diagnosis of severe aortic stenosis (peak gradient of 75 mmHg  mean gradient of 48 mmHg  and an aortic valve area of 0.8 cm²). There were no signs of left ventricular systolic dysfunction.  Discussion  Studies have shown that  in the United States  the prevalence of aortic stenosis is highest amongst White individuals than African-Americans. This case is particularly interesting given the lower incidence of AS in African-Americans.  Currently  the patient is asymptomatic. Therefore  the conundrum lies in whether to proceed with aortic valve replacement surgery as per current guidelines vs. continue with active surveillance per his asymptomatic status. It is a critical balance and requires careful assessment and shared decision-making with the patient.  Conclusion  This case report demonstrates that aortic stenosis can occur in any demographic  even those considered at lower risk such as African-Americans. It emphasizes the importance of physical examinations in asymptomatic patients and the challenging decision-making processes involved in managing asymptomatic severe aortic stenosis. Further research needs to be pursued to fully understand the incidence and management of AS across different demographics.   Keywords: Aortic Stenosis  African-American  Asymptomatic  Case Report

Title: Complex Case of Aortic Valve Stosis in a Middle-aged Female  Patient Profile:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female who presented with symptoms suggestive of aortic valve  stenosis. She is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history of smoking  quit 10 years ago. She is of average  weight and height. The patient is a retired school teacher  a mother of two children  and currently lives alone.  Presenting Symptoms: She complained of recurrent episodes of syncope and exertional dyspnea  which has been progressing over the past six months. Her dyspnea is classified as NYHA Class II  indicating a slight limitation of physical activity. She also mentioned intermittent episodes of chest discomfort and palpitations. The patient denied experiencing current chest pain or discomfort at rest.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension for 10 years  well-controlled on medications  including Hydrochlorothiazide and Lisinopril. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago  which is managed with diet control and metformin. She also has a history of mild osteoarthritis and hyperlipidemia. There is no known history of heart disease in her family.   Physical Examination: Physical examination showed a systolic ejection murmur heard best in the right upper sternal border  which increased in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver. The patient's heart rate was 78 bpm  blood pressure was 135/85 mmHg  and her oxygen saturation was 96% in room air.   Investigations & Diagnosis: Trans-thoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed left ventricular hypertrophy  an ensemble sign of chronic pressure overload from the aortic stenosis. The estimated aortic valve area was 0.9 cm2  consistent with severe aortic stenosis  and Mild aortic regurgitation was also noted. EKG showed a regular rhythm without ST or T wave changes. Her blood work came back with normal renal function  mild raised HbA1C  and cholesterol levels were marginally elevated.   Management: The Heart Team after consultation recommended Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR) due to her being at high risk with surgical aortic valve replacement due to her comorbidities. In the interim  beta-blockers were started to manage her symptoms.   Conclusion: This case provides insight into the management decisions made for a moderate-risk individual with aortic valve stenosis  considering her age  comorbidities and symptom severity. Early recognition of symptoms leading to diagnosis and appropriate guideline-directed treatment can significantly improve the patient's quality of life and overall prognosis.

Title: Aortic Valve Stenosis in an elderly Female patient: A Case Report  Case Presentation: The patient is an 81-year-old African American female with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. She is a non-smoker and denies any history of alcohol or drug abuse. She has been living independently  with her daily activities not requiring assistance. She adopted a balanced diet with intentionally limited sodium and sugar intake considering her health conditions.   Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes and hypertension 20 years ago and had hyperlipidemia for 25 years. She has been managing these conditions with oral hypoglycemic agents  ACE inhibitors  and statins. She had no history of any cardiac disease until the present condition.   Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and occasional angina over the past six months. She also reported experiencing episodes of dizziness and occasional fainting spells during the same period.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient was found to have an audible systolic murmur best heard over the right second intercostal space  radiating to the carotid arteries. Her blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg  pulse 78 bpm and lab results indicated slightly elevated cholesterol level and controlled blood glucose level.  Investigations: An electrocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy. The echocardiogram demonstrated severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 0.8 cm² (normal > 2 cm²) and a notably calcified aortic valve  with mild left ventricular function impairment.  Management & Outcome: Given her age  comorbidities and severity of symptoms  she was treated with Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement(TAVR) procedure  considering it less invasive than surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR). This option was also selected based on her preference for less invasive treatment  post-operative recovery time  and overall condition to withstand the surgery. Post-procedure  her symptoms of dyspnea and angina have improved significantly. She is currently in follow-up and her latest echocardiogram shows a well-functioning prosthetic aortic valve.  Discussion: Aortic valve stenosis is common in the elderly population with multiple comorbidities which makes management challenging. As in this case  TAVR presents a less invasive alternative to SAVR for high-risk individuals. This case reinforces the need for careful clinical assessment and treatment personalization in the elderly population  in whom morbidity and mortality from both the disease and intervention are high.

Title: Severe Aortic Stineosis in an Elderly Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  Aortic stenosis (AS) is a common degenerative condition characterized by the narrowing of the aortic valve opening. AS is associated with considerable morbidity and mortality rates if left untreated.  Case Presentation: An 82-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to the cardiology ward of our hospital presenting progressive exertional dyspnea  chest discomfort  and decreased exercise tolerance over the past four months. His past medical history was significant for hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and smoking (30 pack-years). He was on medications including Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. His history did not reveal any prior heart surgery or congenital heart disease. He had no known allergies. His family history was significant for cardiovascular disease (father died of myocardial infarction).   Physical examination showed the patient was afebrile with a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg and a heart rate of 68 beats/min. Auscultation revealed a harsh systolic ejection murmur radiating to the carotids.   Investigations: An electrocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy. The lipid profile was significant for slightly elevated LDL cholesterol (130 mg/dl). A biomarker for cardiac injury  Troponin T  was within the reference range. A transthoracic echocardiogram revealed severe AS with an aortic valve area of 0.8 cm² (normal >2 cm²)  a peak velocity of 4.4 m/s  and a mean gradient of 50 mmHg. The patient's left ventricular ejection fraction was preserved at 60%.   A coronary angiogram was performed for further evaluation and indicated multivessel coronary artery disease along with severe AS.   Management and Follow-up: The patient was managed conservatively with the continuation of his angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and statin therapy. The patient was started on a low dose of a beta-blocker (metoprolol).   Given the symptomatic severe AS  a multidisciplinary team case conference was held. The patient's advanced age  comorbidities  and multi-vessel coronary artery disease marked him as high risk for surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR). Therefore  the decision was made in favor of transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) procedure and revascularization with coronary artery stents.  Outcome: The patient underwent successful TAVR and coronary stenting. Postoperative recovery was uneventful. Subsequent 3 & 6 month follow-up visits demonstrated a significant improvement in his functional status and exercise tolerance.   Conclusion: The case emphasizes the importance of early detection and appropriate management of aortic stenosis in maintaining the quality of life among elderly patients. Alongside  it demonstrates the viability of transcatheter procedures in patients marked high risk for traditional surgical interventions.

Title: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Female with a History of Hypertension and Atrial Fibrillation  Patient Demographics: The patient is an 80-year-old African American female  residing in a rural locale in South Carolina. She is a retired administrative employee and lives with her 83-year-old husband. She is a non-smoker and has a history of light alcohol consumption.  Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation  both managed with regular medication. Records show that she was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years back and atricval fibrillation around 5 years ago. She is also on a regular dose of anticoagulants. She has no known drug allergies. The patient does not have a history of diabetes or hyperlipidemia. Family history shows her mother suffered from heart disease and passed away at the age of 78.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient presented to the emergency department primarily complaining of shortness of breath  chest discomfort and episodes of dizziness. She shared that she had experienced episodic breathlessness and fatigue over the past 3 months  which had worsened in the past week. Her symptoms seem exaggerated during exertion  most commonly while climbing stairs.  Clinical Assessments and Diagnosis:  Physical examination of the patient revealed a systolic ejection murmur with irradiation to the neck  and mild lower extremity edema  indicative of heart failure. An electrocardiogram confirmed the presence of atrial fibrillation  and showed left ventricular hypertrophy. Following the EKG  an echocardiography was done which revealed a calcified aortic valve  and severely reduced aortic valve area  consistent with severe aortic valve stenosis. The left ventricle appeared hypertrophied  suggesting that the stenosis has been present for a while.  Management and Treatment:  The patient's age and underlying health condition were considered before deciding on her treatment plan. Given the patient’s symptoms  age  and cardiac condition  she was deemed high risk for surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR). With this in mind  the decision was taken to proceed with a Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR)  a less-invasive procedure suitable for high-risk patients. Post-procedure  she will continue her medication for hypertension and atrial fibrillation.   Patient Outcomes and Follow-up:  The patient successfully underwent Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement without any complications and noted significant improvement in her symptoms over the following weeks. She was observed in the hospital for a few days post-procedure and was discharged after her condition was stabilized. She will be followed up in the outpatient clinic after six weeks and will also be monitored regularly for her hypertension and atrial fibrillation condition.   This case report represents an elderly population suffering from severe aortic valve stenosis  commonly seen as a comorbidity with hypertension and atrial fibrillation. It outlines the process of identifying the condition and the tailored decision-making approach used to decide on a minimally invasive method of treatment  taking into account the patient's overall health status and risk factors.

Case Report: Aortic Valve Stenosis in a 75-Year-Old Caucasian Female  Patient Information: The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian female  living in the suburban area of Austin  Texas. She has been living alone after her husband's death five years ago. She has two daughters who live nearby and assist with her daily activities. Prior to retirement  the patient was a high school teacher.  Medical History: Her past medical history reveals she is a type-II diabetic and has been managing it for the last 20 years through lifestyle changes and oral hypoglycemic agents. She has hypertension for which she's been on ACE inhibitors for the last 10 years. She was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation 5 years ago and has been on warfarin therapy since then. Currently  she's maintaining an INR between 2-3. She has no known allergies. She was a smoker (10 sticks per day) but quit when diagnosed with hypertension.  Presenting Complaint: She presented with progressive exertional dyspnea  chest discomfort  left-sided chest pain  and occasional fainting spells that have worsened over the last 6 months. The patient denied having any paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  or peripheral edema. However  she affirmed that her symptoms were restricting her daily activities and interfering with her quality of life.   Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed the patient to have a BMI of 29. She had a mildly distressed appearance. Her blood pressure was 150/90  pulse: 82 bpm  irregular. Respiratory rate was 20 breaths/minute  temperature: 98.6°F. Cardiovascular examination demonstrated a palpable thrill at the right upper sternal border  an ejection systolic murmur best heard over the aortic area  and a soft S2.    Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram revealed atrial fibrillation and left ventricular hypertrophy. The chest X-ray indicated cardiomegaly. Echocardiography confirmed severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 0.8 cm2  calcified aortic cusps  and moderate left ventricular hypertrophy. Left ventricle ejection fraction was 55%.  Therapeutic Intervention: After liaising with the patient  family  and hospital’s cardiac team  a decision was made to proceed with aortic valve replacement (AVR). Given the patient's age and other risk factors  the team chose a transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) approach.   Follow-up: The patient tolerated the procedure well and showed no immediate complication post-procedure. Follow-up echocardiogram showed competent aortic valve prosthesis with no paravalvular leak. At her 6 months follow-up  her symptoms had remarkably improved.  This case has been a classic example of aortic stenosis presenting in an elderly patient. She presented late with severe symptomatic aortic stenosis and was successfully managed with TAVR.

Title: Aortic Valve Stosisos in a Caucasian Female: An Uncommon Case Study of Rapid Degenerative Progression   INTRODUCTION  We present a case report of a 78-year-old Caucasian female patient with rapidly progressive aortic valve stenosis complicated by left ventricular hypertrophy. Despite her numeric age  she has largely been healthy  with controlled hypertension and hypothyroidism.  PATIENT INFORMATION  The female patient  a retired teacher  non-smoker  and occasional alcohol consumer  reported checking into our emergency department with a chief complaint of progressive exertional dyspnea  left-sided chest pain  and fainting spells over the past few weeks. She had a history of modestly controlled hypertension and hypothyroidism but no history or signs of rheumatic fever  endocarditis  renal disease  diabetes  or other comorbidities; these may provide a link to her present condition.  CLINICAL FINDINGS  Upon examination  the patient had an irregular pulse of 78 bpm  blood pressure of 150/92 mmHg  respiratory rate of 14 per minute  and SpO2 at 95%. She exhibited mild pallor but no cyanosis  clubbing  or lymphadenopathy. Auscultation revealed a prominent systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border  with radiation to the carotids.   DIAGNOSTIC ASSESSMENT  The electrocardiogram underscored left ventricular hypertrophy  and the initial chest X-ray indicated a slightly enlarged cardiac silhouette without pulmonary congestion. Echocardiography showed severe aortic valve stenosis with a calculated aortic valve area of 0.8cm2  a peak gradient of 70mmHg  and a mean gradient of 40mmHg. The left ventricle was noticeably hypertrophied with a moderately impaired ejection fraction of 45%. Carotid and Renal Doppler showed no significant abnormalities.  THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTION   Aortic valve replacement was recommended given the severe symptomatic status of aortic stenosis and the risks associated with her impairment.  FOLLOW-UP AND OUTCOMES   Two weeks post-operatively  the patient exhibited a significant improvement in terms of symptoms and general well-being. She remains under regular check-up and medications for her co-morbid conditions.  DISCUSSION  This case underscores the rapid nature of progression in aortic valve stenosis and the profound effect of this condition on the quality of life. Sudden deterioration in an otherwise stable patient underlines the need for early valve replacement to prevent irreversible heart damage.  CONCLUSION  Aortic stenosis  though often a disease of the elderly  can manifest rapidly and detrimentally even in a patient with previously stable cardiac status. This calls for a systematic approach in identification  prognosis prediction  and early intervention to prevent rapid deterioration.    Patient consent was obtained for this case report.

Title: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Asian Female: A Case Report  1. Patient Information The patient is a 78-year-old Asian female resident from Taiwan  with a height of 156 cm and weight of 56 kg  leading to a body mass index (BMI) of 22.9 kg/m^2  within the normal range.  2. Chief Complaint The patient sought medical care  complaining of shortness of breath during exertion  occasional episodes of chest pain  palpitations  and dizzy spells for the past six months.  3. Medical History The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago and is currently on antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. She has never smoked or consumed alcohol and follows a balanced diet. There was no history of rheumatic fever  although as a child  she had frequent throat infections that may point towards an undiagnosed streptococcal infection  a leading cause of aortic valve disease. The patient had a transient ischemic attack 6 years ago  and there is no family history of heart disease or sudden death.  4. Clinical Findings On examination  the patient exhibited a systolic murmur  and an electrocardiogram (ECG) showed left ventricle hypertrophy (LVH). She was slightly hypertensive with a blood pressure of 150/85 mmHg. Her heart rate was 90 BPM  and her atrial blood oxygenation was 97%. The blood tests indicated elevated cholesterol levels and slightly elevated HbA1C levels  indicating suboptimal diabetic control.  5. Timeline Echo Doppler was performed immediately following the clinical evaluation  revealing severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 0.8 cm^2 and a mean gradient of 50 mmHg with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. The patient was then referred to a cardiologist for further management.  6. Diagnostic Assessment  Based on her symptoms and results from echocardiography  the patient was diagnosed with severe aortic valve stenosis.  7. Therapeutic Intervention The patient was recommended for transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) due to her age and co-existing conditions. Medication for her hypertension was reviewed and optimized  and she was prescribed statins for her elevated cholesterol levels. Diabetic control was discussed and dietitian review arranged.  8. Follow-up Post-TAVR  the patient reported a significant improvement in her symptoms. In the following weeks  she showed good progress with her blood pressure and diabetes well controlled. The patient continues to be monitored on a regular basis with six-monthly follow-ups  including echocardiograms and blood tests.  9. Patient Perspective The patient is happy with her medical management and appreciative that previously debilitating symptoms have markedly improved  increasing her quality of life.  10. Conclusion In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of timely diagnosis and management in treating aortic valve stenosis  especially in elderly patients with multiple co-morbidities. Additionally  it emphasizes the significance of echo Doppler in diagnosing aortic stenosis and how age and lifestyle diseases like hypertension and diabetes can affect the disease's progression.

Title: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in Middle-Aged Female: A Case Report  Patient Description: The patient is a 58-year-old African-American female from an urban setting  standing 5'7"" and weighing 162 pounds  (BMI at 25.4). She’s a retired school teacher who has never smoked or consumed alcohol. She lives alone but is independent and maintains strong relationships with family and friends. Further  she follows a balanced diet but has a sedentary lifestyle.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented herself to the clinic with direct complaints of progressive dyspnea on exertion and occasional chest tightness for the past six months.   Past Medical History: She has a documented history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia over the past ten years. However  she has been compliant with her antihypertensive medication  Lisinopril 10mg once daily and atorvastatin 20mg once daily for lower cholesterol. She is also on daily low-dose aspirin. Her hypertension and cholesterol levels have been well-controlled with these measures. Her familial history is positive for cardiovascular diseases  with her father experiencing myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and her maternal uncle undergoing aortic valve replacement for severe aortic stenosis at the age of 60.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  she appeared to be in mild distress due to dyspnea. Vital signs recorded were as follows: blood pressure 138/85mmHg  HR 78 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 per minute  oxygen saturation at room air 96%. Examination of the cardiovascular system revealed the presence of an ejection systolic murmur on the right second intercostal space that radiates to the carotid arteries.  Investigations: Cardiac echocardiography was performed revealing a reduced aortic valve opening (0.8 cm2) along with an increased peak aortic valve gradient (mean gradient: 60mmHg)  left ventricular hypertrophy  and mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction (EF: 55%). Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed left ventricular hypertrophy. Other routine blood parameters were found to be within normal limits except for slightly raised LDL cholesterol.  Diagnosis: She was diagnosed with severe aortic valve stenosis based on her clinical finding  ECG  and Doppler echocardiographic evaluation.  Treatment and Outcome: Given the diagnosis of severe aortic valve stenosis  she was referred to the cardiovascular surgical department for aortic valve replacement. She was prepared for surgery and successfully underwent aortic valve replacement with a biological prosthetic valve. She was also prescribed a regimen of statin  aspirin  and antihypertensive medication which was continued post-surgery. Her post-operative period was uneventful  and her symptoms of dyspnea and chest discomfort diminished significantly. She was encouraged to adopt a more active lifestyle.  Conclusion: This case reiterates the importance of timely diagnosis and appropriate management in aortic stenosis  a condition more prevalent in the elderly  but that can occur in middle-aged individuals as well. It further emphasizes that a high level of suspicion should be maintained in patients with significant or unexplained symptoms and a known history of cardiovascular risk factors.

Title: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Aortic valve stenosis  prevalence of which increases with age  is most commonly due to progressive calcific degenerative changes. This report describes the case of an 80-year-old Caucasian male patient with severe aortic valve stenosis.  Case Presentation:  Demographics and Medical History: Mr. A  an 80-year-old retired teacher and life-long non-smoker  presented to our clinic with a history of progressive breathlessness on exertion over the last 8 months. He also reported episodes of dizziness and had a recent fall without losing consciousness. His past medical history was significant for hypertension  managed with an ACE inhibitor  and a myocardial infarction 10 years ago that was treated with balloon angioplasty and stent placement.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  he was afebrile with a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg and heart rate of 70 beats per minute. Cardiovascular examination revealed a grade 3 early peaking systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border with radiation to the carotids  suggestive of aortic stenosis. No other significant findings were present on physical examination.  Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy with repolarisation changes. Echocardiography confirmed severe aortic stenosis with a bicuspid aortic valve  a peak gradient of 85 mmHg  mean gradient of 50 mmHg  and an aortic valve area of 0.8 cm2. Left ventricular ejection fraction was 55% indicating preserved systolic function. Coronary angiography carried out due to his past history of ischemic heart disease revealed a 50-60% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery  which was managed medically.  Treatment: Considering the patient’s age  comorbidities and severe stenosis  he was considered a high-risk candidate for surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR). Following consultation with the heart team  it was decided to proceed with transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). The procedure was successfully carried out without complications  and a post-procedural echocardiogram showed a well-functioning bioprosthetic valve with a peak gradient of 18mmHg.  Outcome and Follow-up: Post-procedure  the patient was monitored in the intensive care unit and then transferred to the general ward. His breathlessness on exertion improved and by the time of discharge  he was able to perform his daily activities without limited by symptoms. He continues to follow up at our cardiology outpatient clinic every 3 months.  Conclusion: Aortic valve stenosis in our ageing population can be associated with serious symptoms and poor prognosis. Hence  early diagnosis and appropriate interventions  such as TAVR in high-risk surgical patients like the one in our case  can improve quality of life and have a favorable impact on survival.

Title: Severe Symptomatic Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  Aortic Stenosis (AS) is a common valvular heart disease prevalent in older adults  with studies suggesting a prevalence of about 3.4% in people aged over 75 years. This report documents the management of a case of severe aortic valve stenosis in a 78-year-old Caucasian male.  Case Presentation:  Mr. A is a 78-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the hospital emergency room with symptoms of exertional angina  syncope  and shortness of breath. His previous medical history includes hypertension controlled by beta-blockers  type II diabetes managed by metformin  and hyperlipidemia treated with statins. Mr. A does not smoke or drink alcohol and leads a reasonably active lifestyle. He has a family history of cardiac diseases  with his father having succumbed to congestive heart failure.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient appeared distressed and having difficulty breathing. His blood pressure was 142/90 mmHg  heart rate was 86 beats per minute irregular  respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. A prominent systolic murmur was detected upon auscultation. ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy with strain pattern. Chest X-ray hinted cardiac enlargement.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed  which revealed severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 0.8 cm²  peak velocity of 4.5 m/s and mean gradient of 50 mmHg  all confirming the diagnosis of severe aortic stenosis. Coronary angiography indicated non-obstructive coronary artery disease. The patient’s ejection fraction was preserved at 55%.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment:  In light of the advanced age and multiple comorbidities of the patient  Mr. A was considered high risk for surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR). Following a detailed discussion of treatment options and risks  Mr. A and his family opted for transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR)  a less invasive option with success in treating high-risk patients.  Mr. A underwent the TAVR procedure successfully. A balloon-expandable valve was deployed  resulting in the immediate resolution of the aortic stenosis. His post-procedural hospital stay was uneventful  and he reported significant improvements in his symptoms at his follow-up visits.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering less invasive procedures like TAVR for elderly  high-risk patients with severe symptomatic aortic valve stenosis. Patient preference  risk profile  and treatment outcomes should dictate the choice of intervention in this demographic group. It also reflects upon the imperative need for early detection and timely management of aortic stenosis  especially among the aged population.

Title: A Case Report on Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Hispanic Female  Introduction:   Aortic valve stenosis (AS) represents an important public health problem  affecting up to 7% of individuals aged over 65 years. The prevalence of severe AS is higher in elderly patients and it is especially poignant in Hispanic and non-Hispanic white populations. We report a case of AS in a 78-year-old Hispanic female patient  with a history of hypertension and type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.  Clinical Presentation:  The patient  a 78-year-old Hispanic female  presented with a month-long history of worsening dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. The patient also complained of episodes of dizziness and fainting. She reported a significant reduction in her ability to perform activities of daily living due to these symptoms. Her past medical history included well-controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and no known drug allergies. She is a non-smoker and rarely drinks alcohol. Her mother and older brother both had cardiac disease.  Clinical Findings and Diagnostic Assessment:  Physical examination revealed a noticeable systolic ejection murmur. Blood pressure was 150/80 mm Hg  pulse rate was regular at 70 beats per minute. Further investigation with echocardiography demonstrated a heavily calcified aortic valve with decreased leaflet mobility. Peak and mean pressure gradients of 60mmHg and 40mmHg  respectively  were noted across the aortic valve  suggesting severe stenosis. The left ventricle appeared hypertrophied with preserved systolic function. This was further confirmed with cardiac CT evidence of severe  calcific aortic valve stenosis with a calculated aortic valve area of 0.9 cm2.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was referred to a multidisciplinary heart team for further management. Given her age  comorbidities  and the severity of her symptoms  she was deemed to be at high risk for surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR). Therefore  the heart team decided upon Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR) which was successfully performed without any immediate complications. Post-procedure  she was placed on dual-antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  a diuretic  an ACE inhibitor  and remained on her usual diabetic medications. She was discharged after 5 days post-procedure and her symptoms significantly improved at the 6-week follow-up visit.  Discussion:  This case illustrates the typical presentation of severe aortic stenosis in an elderly patient with multiple comorbidities. It emphasizes the role of echocardiography in the diagnosis  assessment of severity of AS  and the importance of teamwork in managing such cases effectively. Despite conventional risk factors for surgery  application of advanced procedures like TAVR can produce beneficial results in elderly patients.  Conclusion:  It is important to meticulously assess elderly individuals who present with exertional dyspnea  as it may be a sign of advanced cardiac conditions like AS. With advancements in treatment procedures such as TAVR  even those deemed at high-risk can potentially achieve improved outcomes and quality of life.

Title: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in a 74-year-old African American Female: A Case Report.  Introduction: Aortic valve stenosis (AS) is a common and serious heart condition characterized by a narrowing at the aortic valve opening. It predominantly occurs in the elderly  with a 2-3% prevalence in individuals above the age of 75 years. A race-based retrospective study shows slightly higher rates of AS among African Americans. Here  we present a case of severe aortic valve stenosis in a 74-year-old African American woman with a strong medical history of cardiovascular disorders.  Case Presentation: The patient  a 74-year-old African American female  presented to our clinic with worsening fatigue and shortness of breath over the course of a year. Past medical history included hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She also has a history of smoking and occasional alcohol consumption. On physical exam  she was noted to have a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur radiating to the neck  diminished pulses  and late peaking pulse suggestive of severe aortic stenosis. Blood pressure was 110/70 mmHg and heart rate was at 88 beats per minute. Breath sounds were clear to auscultation.  An electrocardiogram (EKG) revealed left ventricular hypertrophy and a chest radiography showed cardiac enlargement. Echocardiogram reported a projected aortic valve area of 0.7cm2  indicating severe aortic stenosis with the left ventricle size and wall thickness within normal limits. The left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) was 60%.  Given her age  clinical history  and presentation  she was considered a risk for surgical valve intervention. Therefore  Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR) was conducted. Post-TAVR  the patient had acceptable heart function with an improved aortic valve area and no apparent procedural complications. She was  then  discharged with an appropriate medication regimen  including high-dose statins  antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy  and follow-up appointments.  Discussion: Incidence of symptomatic aortic stenosis is increasing  particularly in the elderly population  making it an outstanding health concern. This case demonstrates the importance of early recognition of symptoms and timely intervention to prevent hemodynamic decompensation. It also emphasizes the efficacy of TAVR as an acceptable therapeutic approach  especially in high-risk surgical patients.  Conclusion: Timely identification and intervention in patients with severe aortic stenosis are paramount  particularly in high-risk populations with a significant history of cardiovascular disorders. Our patient's improvement post-TAVR signifies its benefits in such cases. However  a comprehensive  individualized approach  encompassing lifestyle modifications and strategic pharmaceutical management  remain integral parts of long-term care in these patients.

Title: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Female Patient  Patient Details and Demographics:  The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian female  a resident of a rural town. The patient is 5’3” tall and weighs approximately 140 lbs. She is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol.  Background and Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of hypertension (Diagnosed 15 years ago) and a family history of cardiovascular diseases. Her father passed away due to myocardial infarction  and her older sister had undergone a coronary artery bypass grafting procedure. She also has controlled type 2 diabetes and previously diagnosed moderate aortic stenosis  which was being monitored for progress. Other than these  she has no known allergies or contraindications to common medications.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient approached the clinic with complaints of recurring episodes of chest pain and exertional dyspnea for the past 6 months. She has also been experiencing fatigue and fainting spells  which has hindered her daily activities.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient appeared mildly distressed. A harsh systolic murmur was audible on cardiac auscultation  best heard in the second right intercostal space. Blood pressure measured was 130/85 mm Hg  heart rate was irregular at 96 beats per minute  and respiratory rate was slightly elevated at 18 breaths per minute. No significant findings were observed on lung auscultation or on examination of other systems.  Investigations:  An electrocardiogram revealed a left ventricular hypertrophy and T-wave inversion. Based on the symptoms and initial findings  a transthoracic echocardiogram was administered. The echo revealed a severely calcified aortic valve  severe aortic stenosis  and an aortic valve area calculated to be 0.8 cm² with a mean gradient of 40mmHg. Left ventricular ejection fraction was reduced at 50%.  Management:  The patient was referred to a cardiologist where surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) was considered over transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) due to her pre-existing conditions and overall health status. After successful completion of the SAVR procedure and post-operative care  the patient was discharged with further instructions to monitor her blood pressure and glucose levels. She was prescribed medications including beta-blockers  diuretics  and statins to manage her heart condition and cholesterol levels.  Discussion:  Severe aortic valve stenosis in the elderly population is often linked with an increased risk of heart failure and mortality. Early diagnosis through regular monitoring  appropriate surgical intervention  and personalized postoperative care  as seen in the case of this patient  significantly improve prognosis. In such instances  SAVR can greatly enhance patient's quality and expectancy of life  enabling them to lead a more comfortable lifestyle. The patient continues to be monitored with regular follow-ups.  Conclusion:  This case report emphasizes the need of tailored management for elderly patients suffering from severe aortic valve stenosis  taking into consideration their overall health status  comorbidities  and lifestyle.

Title: Degenerative Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  Degenerative aortic stenosis  most often consequent of age-related calcific changes  is the most common valvular heart disease in the Western world and the third most common cardiovascular disease after hypertension and coronary artery disease. In this case report  we describe the diagnostic process  management  and follow-up of an elderly patient with aortic stenosis (AS).  Case Presentation:  The patient is an 80-year-old Caucasian male  retired military veteran  presenting to the cardiology outpatient clinic with progressively worsening exercise intolerance and exertional chest discomfort for six months. He reported that his symptoms have impaired his quality of life  as he can no longer perform his routine tasks as previously. He has not experienced any syncope  palpitations or dyspnoea at rest. He does not smoke  and reports occasional alcohol consumption. His medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been on Lisinopril and Metformin for the past ten years. He has no known drug allergies. Family history revealed that his father died from a myocardial infarction in his sixties.  Examination:  Physical examination revealed a body mass index (BMI) of 28 kg/m2  blood pressure 145/90 mm Hg  pulse rate 78 beats per minute  and regular rhythm. His oxygen saturation was 97% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed a grade 3/6 ejection systolic murmur and no signs of heart failure. There were no abnormal findings on respiratory  abdominal and neurological examination.  Investigations:  Electrocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy. Blood tests indicated HbA1c value of 7.8%  mildly elevated LDL cholesterol  and normal kidney function. The chest X-ray was unremarkable. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) demonstrated a thickened and calcified aortic valve  reduced leaflet excursion  and a peak velocity of 4.2 m/s  consistent with severe AS. Left ventricle seemed hypertrophied with preserved ejection fraction.  Management and Follow Up:  A shared decision-making discussion took place about the possible interventions – surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) and transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). Considering the patient’s age  symptomatic status and possible surgical risks  the recommendation was made for TAVR.   The procedure was successful  and the patient was discharged on the third postoperative day. At the six-month follow-up  the patient reported a significant improvement in his symptoms and quality of life.  Conclusion:  This case report highlights the typical presentation of an elderly patient with severe degenerative aortic stenosis  an increasingly common condition in our aging population. Timely intervention with TAVR significantly improved the patient's symptomatic status and quality of life. Regular follow-ups are necessary to monitor potential complications and ensure optimal management.

Title: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Female Patient with a History of Hypertension  Patient Information:  An 83-year-old Caucasian woman presented to the outpatient department of our institution. She is a retired school teacher living with her daughter and son-in-law. She is a former smoker  with a 30-pack year history but had quit smoking 20 years ago. She has been diagnosed with hypertension for over ten years  which has been managed with antihypertensive therapy (amlodipine 5mg once daily). She denies any history of illicit drug use  alcohol intake or family history of heart disease. She has no known drug allergies.   Clinical Findings:  The patient complained about progressive exertional dyspnea and general fatigue over the previous 6 months  with symptoms becoming significantly worse in the past 3 weeks. She reported an episode of syncope two days ago  which prompted her visit. The patient was unable to perform her regular activities such as walking without feeling breathless. No chest pain or palpitations were reported.   On physical exam  a midsystolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border and a prominent 'delayed' carotid upstroke were noted. The patient's blood pressure was 154/88 mmHg  heart rate was 78 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation was 95% on room air.  Diagnostic Assessment and Therapeutic Intervention:  A comprehensive set of investigations including blood tests  echocardiogram  electrocardiogram  and chest radiography were conducted. Abnormal blood tests included elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) at 450 pg/mL (normal <100 pg/mL). Echocardiogram showed severely calcified aortic valve with reduced opening  and an estimated aortic valve area of 0.8 cm2  consistent with severe aortic stenosis. Left ventricular ejection fraction was preserved  and there was evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy likely secondary to longstanding hypertension and aortic stenosis.  In consultation with a multidisciplinary team involving cardiology  geriatrics  and cardiac surgery  the decision was made to proceed with transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) given her advanced age  symptomatology  and severe aortic stenosis. Post-procedure  her symptoms subsided and she was discharged with a strict follow-up plan.  Case Outcome:  Two months following TAVR  the patient was readmitted for a routine post-procedural review. Her symptoms of exertional dyspnea and general fatigue had remarkably improved. She was content with her quality of life. On exam  the systolic murmur was much softer and her carotid upstroke was normal in timing.  Discussion:  Aortic stenosis is the most common valvular heart disease in the elderly and is often associated with significant morbidity and mortality if left untreated. A timely diagnosis and appropriate intervention are essential. This case emphasizes the increasing importance of TAVR as a treatment option in the elderly population with severe aortic stenosis who may not be ideal candidates for surgical aortic valve replacement due to comorbid conditions and advanced age.

Title: Aortic Valve Stenosis in a Geriatric Asian Female Patient with Hypertension: A Case Report   Introduction: Aortic Valve Stenosis (AVS) is a chronic cardiovascular disease that is predominantly seen in geriatric populations or those who have a congenital valve defect. The following case report describes a septuagenarian female patient with clinical symptoms pertaining to aortic stenosis  with an underlying history of hypertension.  Case Report:  Patient Profile:  A 75-year-old Asian female presented to our outpatient department  with progressive symptoms of dyspnea on exertion  chest tightness and recurrent fatigue over the last 4 months. She had a past medical history of hypertension  for which she was taking a calcium channel blocker. Madam X  a non-smoker  led a sedentary lifestyle and had a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with her late father suffering from coronary artery disease and her mother having hypertension.   Examination & Diagnosis: Upon physical examination  a systolic murmur was noted  radiating to the carotid arteries. Her blood pressure was considered stable at 130/80 mmHg with regular pulse rate. Non-invasive tests including a Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) and a 12-lead ECG were ordered. The ECG showed normal sinus rhythm but with left ventricular hypertrophy  while the TTE found severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 0.8 cm2  left ventricular hypertrophy and mild LV dysfunction  confirming the diagnosis of severe aortic valve stenosis (AVS).  Management: In view of her symptoms  hypertension history  and severe AVS  a joint decision was made to proceed with a transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). Post TAVR  her symptoms of dyspnea and fatigue noticeably improved.  Conclusion: This case highlights the common association with acquired conditions like hypertension in patients suffering from AVS. Regular follow-ups and adherence to hypertension medications along with the timely intervention for AVS are key to avoid potential complications and improve the patient's quality of life. Further  it advocates for increased awareness and screening for AVS in geriatric individuals with a history of hypertension to facilitate early diagnosis and appropriate management.   Demographics and baseline characteristics:  Age: 75 years  Gender: Female Race: Asian  Family History: Positive for Hypertension and Coronary artery disease Smoking: Non-smoker Lifestyle: Sedentary Medical History: Hypertension Clinical symptoms: Dyspnea on exertion  chest tightness  recurrent fatigue. Measurements: Heart rate: Regular  Blood Pressure: 130/80 mmHg Diagnostic tests results: Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE) showed severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 0.8 cm2  left ventricular hypertrophy and mild LV dysfunction. ECG showed normal sinus rhythm with left ventricular hypertrophy. Management: Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR)

Title: A Case Report of Aortic Valve Stosensis in a 75-Year-Old African-American Female Patient   Patient Information:  The patient is a 75-year-old African-American female  married  and a retired schoolteacher living in urban Atlanta  Georgia. Her height and weight at the time of the report were 165 cm and 75 kg  respectively  rendering a body mass index (BMI) of 27.5 kg/m^2 indicating overweight status.   Medical History:  The patient had a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and had been on antihypertensive and statin treatment for the past 15 years. She was a nonsmoker and reported moderate alcohol consumption at social gatherings. There was no known drug abuse or allergy history. Familial medical history suggested ascending aortic aneurysm in her deceased father while her mother was a diabetes mellitus type II patient.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient came with a chief complaint of recurrent shortness of breath on exertion  occasional chest discomfort  and episodes of dizziness over the previous six months. She initially ignored these symptoms  attributing them to aging and weight gain. However  the symptoms had progressively worsened over the last one month  disrupting her daily activities and prompting her consultation.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a decreased intensity of the second heart sound  pulsus parvus et tardus  and an ejection systolic murmur heard best at the second right intercostal space radiating to the carotids. There was no history of syncope  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Examination of other systems did not reveal any abnormal findings.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An electrocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy. A transthoracic echo showed calcified aortic valve leaflets with reduced opening and a peak velocity of 4.5 m/sec  indicating severe aortic stenosis. The left ventricle was hypertrophied with preserved systolic function. Coronary angiogram revealed no significant coronary artery disease.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Following consultation with the heart team  she was scheduled for a transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). She underwent a successful TAVR procedure without complications. Following the procedure  she was managed with aspirin  beta blockers  and continued her existing medications for hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Follow-up and outcomes:  At a 6-month follow-up visit  the patient reported significant improvement in her symptoms  being able to conduct daily activities without excessive fatigue or breathlessness. Her follow-up Echo showed normal functioning of the replaced aortic valve with mean gradient of 15mmHg.  Patient Consent:  The patient provided informed consent for this case report.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of early recognition and intervention in elderly patients presenting with worsening breathlessness and typical signs  which may be indicative of aortic valve stenosis. Patient demographics may make diagnosing and treating such patients challenging. However  with timely intervention  their quality of life can be significantly improved  as observed in this case.

Title: Progression and Management of Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in a 68-Year Old African-American Male  Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old African American male  a retired steelworker  currently residing in Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania. He is widowed  a father of two adult children  and a self-proclaimed moderate drinker and ex-smoker  having quit smoking 20 years ago.   Clinical Findings:  The patient initially reported progressive shortness of breath on exertion  chest tightness  and occasional dizziness for the past six months. He has a BMI of 28  indicative of being overweight  and suffers from hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are both controlled with medication.   Diagnostic Assessment:  Initial 12-lead ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy. Two-dimensional transthoracic echocardiography revealed the presence of a calcified aortic valve with limited movement and a left ventricular outflow tract velocity  which suggested severe aortic stenosis. Other laboratory studies indicated normal full blood count  renal function  and thyroid function.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Considering the patient's clinical presentation and echocardiographic findings  he was categorized as a high-risk patient due to his existing comorbidities. The interdisciplinary cardiac team discussed several management strategies  including surgical aortic valve replacement (AVR) and transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI). Given the patient's high surgical risk  TAVI was chosen as the preferred method. The procedure went smoothly without immediate complications.   Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient was discharged home on the fifth postoperative day. Post-procedural recovery was unremarkable  with a dramatic improvement in exertional symptoms. Repeat echocardiography 30-days post-TAVI illustrated a well-functioning bioprosthetic aortic valve with no transvalvular gradient or paravalvular leak. The patient continues to make steady progress with regular follow-up in the outpatient clinic.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed relief at his improved symptoms and ability to perform daily activities with increased energy. He expressed gratitude for the thorough explanation of the procedural benefits and risks  allowing him to make an informed decision about his health.   Learning Points:  This case illuminates the importance of early recognition and appropriate management of aortic valve stenosis  especially in a high-risk population. It also underscores the effectiveness of innovative therapeutic options such as TAVI in patients who may not be ideal candidates for traditional surgical approaches. Regular follow-ups and health education play a vital role in managing postoperative complications and ensuring good long-term outcomes.

Case Report: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Older Female Patient  Patient Demographics: Ms. D  a 74-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  comes from a suburban area of Seattle  Washington. She lives with her two cats and is a non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption.  Presenting Condition: The patient presented to the clinic with complaints of progressive breathlessness and fatigue while engaging in everyday activities  specifically walking up stairs or carrying groceries. She also reported recurrent episodes of dizziness over the past 3 to 4 months.  Medical History: Ms. D has a long-standing history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been well-controlled with medication (Lisinopril and Rosuvastatin  respectively). She was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus ten years prior to her current presentation and has been maintaining her blood glucose levels with Metformin. She previously underwent an appendectomy at the age of 25 and a cesarean section at the age of 30. She has been relatively healthy otherwise.  Examination and Testing: Clinical examination revealed a mid-systolic ejection murmur heard on auscultation along the left sternal border and radiating to the carotids. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy  and chest X-ray showed cardiomegaly. She was immediately referred to cardiology for further assessment.  Echocardiography confirmed severe aortic valve stenosis (AS) with a valve area of 0.8 cm2  a mean gradient of 45 mmHg  and peak velocity at 4.5 m/s. The left ventricle showed concentric remodeling but preserved ejection fraction at 55%. Cardiac catheterization showed moderate coronary artery disease  which was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention and stent placement.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was referred for a trans-catheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR)  given her age and the severity of the stenosis. Post-TAVR  the patient showed significant relief from her symptoms. At her one-month follow-up appointment  Ms. D reported that she was already noticing an improvement in her stamina and significantly lesser episodes of breathlessness and dizziness.  In summary  this case representation highlights the importance of considering aortic stenosis in older patients presenting with dyspnea  decreased exercise tolerance  and dizziness. With a history of cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes increases the likelihood. Timely diagnosis and intervention can drastically improve the patient’s quality of life and prognosis.

Title: Severe Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Female Patient: A Case Report  Patient Information: The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian female. She is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. The patient is a retired school teacher  living with her daughter and grandchild in an urban residence in Wisconsin. She has a prior history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication  and a BMI of 28.  Case Presentation:  The patient presented to the clinic with complaints of exertional dyspnea and increasing fatigue over the past six months. She reported difficulty with activities of daily living (ADLs) due to shortness of breath and generalized weakness.  Clinical Findings: The patient's vital signs were within normal limits. Upon physical examination  the patient was conscious  cooperative  with no signs of distress at rest. Auscultation revealed a systolic murmur. Both the lungs were clear on auscultation  and the abdomen was soft and non-tender. There was no peripheral edema.   Timeline: Considering her increasing symptoms over half a year  coupled with her medical history and physical examination  a possible cardiovascular etiology was suspected. The patient was further evaluated over three visits spanning a month  where she underwent various diagnostic procedures.  Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram (EKG) showed left ventricular hypertrophy. The subsequent echocardiography revealed severe aortic valve stenosis with a valve area of 0.8cm2 and moderate concentric left ventricular hypertrophy. Her left ventricle ejection fraction was estimated at 55%. A cardiac catheterization confirmed these findings.  Therapeutic Intervention: Considering her age  comorbidities  and the severity of the stenosis  the patient was offered a transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) as a less invasive alternative to surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR). The patient accepted the TAVR approach. The procedure was successful without major complications.  Follow-up and Outcome: On a follow-up visit 3 months post-procedure  the patient reported significant improvement in symptoms  now capable of performing her ADLs without dyspnea or fatigue. A repeat echocardiography confirmed a well-functioning prosthetic valve with no significant gradient.   Patient Perspective: The patient expressed her satisfaction with the treatment and improvement in her quality of life.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of early identification and timely management of aortic valve stenosis  especially in elderly patients with multiple comorbidities. It also highlights the benefits of less invasive procedures like TAVR in such patients. Further  individualized patient-centred care can result in a significant improvement in symptoms and quality of life in these patients.   Informed Consent:  Informed written consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Title: Symptomatic Aortic Valve Stenosis in an Elderly Female: A Case Report   Introduction:  The following case report describes a patient with progressive symptoms of aortic valve stenosis (AS). Although AS is a common disorder affecting up to 7% of the elderly population above 65 years  it remains a grave condition due to its potential complications  including heart failure and sudden death.  Patient Information: The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian female living in a suburban residential area. She had been a schoolteacher by profession until her retirement about 20 years ago. She has been widowed for the past 8 years  and her family constitutes three children  who are all grown  married  and living separately.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the outpatient clinic with the primary complaint of shortness of breath of progressively increasing severity over the past six months. She also reported having episodes of chest discomfort that subsides at rest and lightheadedness. Further direct queries revealed intermittent episodes of syncope and palpitations. Her everyday activities have become increasingly restricted due to the consistent feeling of fatigue and weakness she experiences.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both under control with oral medication. There is also a history of dyslipidemia managed with a statin. She reported no history of smoking  alcohol or drug use.   Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram (ECG) displayed left ventricular hypertrophy. Blood work including complete blood count  renal function tests  and electrolytes were within normal ranges. Echocardiography confirmed severe aortic valve stenosis with calcification and a reduced aortic valve area. The left ventricle showed signs of hypertrophy with preserved ejection fraction.
